LONDON:

Printed by George Eyre and Andrew Strahan, Printers to the King’s most Excellent Majesty.

Cap. i.

An Act to continue and amend an Act passed in tly Seventeenth Year of His present Majesty, for repairing the Road from the Town of Derby through jipibome to Hurdloe House in the County of Derby. [22c! February 1805.3

WHEREAS an Act was passed in the seventeenth Year of the

Reign of His present Majesty, intituled, An Act for repealing so ,7 Qm 3 much of Two Acts, made in the Eleventh and Seventeenth Years of the Reign of King George the Second, for repairing several Roads leading to and from the Town of Derbv, in the County of Derby, as relates to the Road leading from the Gaol Bridge, in the said Town of Derby, through the Town of A fh borne to Hurdloe House, in the said County, for making more effectual Provision for the Repair of the said Road, and for enabling the Trustees to alter Part of the Course of the present Road between Ashborne and the New Inn Turnpike: And whereas great Progress hath been made in repairing and widening the said Road, and several Sums of Money are now due and owing on the Credit of the Tolls thereby granted, which cannot be paid off, nor the said Road kept in Repair unlel's the Term of the said Act is further continued, and the Powers thereof altered and enlarged: May it therefore pleale your Majesty,

An Act to indemnify all Persons employed in the Disposal,of Coals in the Coal Market in the City of London, who have incurred Penalties under certain Provisions of an Act, made in the Forty-third Year of-Elis present Majesty, for establi (Ling a free Market in the City of London for the Sale of Coals, and for preventing Frauds and Impodtions in the Vend and Delivery of all Coals brought into the Port of Londonwithin certain Places therein mentioned.

And be it further enacted, That it shall and may be lawful, to and for the said Surveyor or Surveyors, and such Person or Persons as he or they ft)all appoint, from Time to Time, without giving any previous Notice, to remove all such Earth, Trees, Roots of Trees, and other Things, as shall Aide or fall, or be blown down from any Hedge, Bank, or Land, into or upon any of the said Roads, so as to narrow or obstrud the Passage through the fame, and to carry and place the fame on any waste Ground near thereto, so as to prevent the fame from being an Annoyance to Travellers; and such Surveyor or Surveyors shall forthwith give Notice thereof to the Owners or Occupiers of the Lands from whence such Earth, Trees, Roots of Trees, or other Things, shall so Aide or fall, or be blown down as aforesaid; and the Charges of carrying away the same shall be reimbursed and paid to such Surveyor or Surveyors, by such Owners or Occupiers respectively, and shall be recovered by such Ways and Means as any Penalties and Forfeitures for Offences against this Act are directed to be recovered.

LIIT. And be it further enacted, That if any Person Aiall hale or draw, or cause to be haled or drawn upon any Part of the said Roads, any Tree, or Piece of Timber, or any Stone, otherwise than on a wheel Carriage, or shall suffer any Part of any Tree or Piece of Timber which shall be conveyed upon any wheel Carriage, to drag upon any Part of such Roads, to the Prejudice thereof; or if any Person or Persons shall drive any Waggon or other Carriage with any Wheel thereof dragged or stopped from going round, upon any Part of the said Roads, where the Descent thereof shall not be more than Two Inches and a Half in the Length of Three Feet, every such Person shall, for every such Offence, forfeit and pay any Sum not exceeding Forty Shillings.

LXIII. Provided always, and be it enacted, That if any Person or Persons Appeal.

shall think himself, herself, or themselves aggrieved by any Thing done in pursuance of this Act, such Person or Persons may appeal to the Justices of the Peace at the first General Quarter Sessions of the Peace holden for the County of Somerset, next after the Expiration of One Calendar Month from the Time such Matter of Appeal shall have arisen, the Person or Persons appealing having first given Ten Days Notice, at lead, of his, her, or their Intention to bring such Appeal, and of the Matter thereof, to the Treasurer or Clerk to the said Trustees, and within Two Days after such Notice entering into a Recognizance before some Justice of the Peace for the said County of Somerset, with Two sufficient Sureties, conditioned to try such Appeal, and to abide the Order and Decision of the said Court thereon; and the said Justices at such Sessions, upon due Proof of such Notice and Recognizance being given and entered into, are hereby authorized and required to hear and determine the Matter of Appeal in a summary Way, and to make such Determination therein, and to award such Costs to either of the Parties, or otherwise as they shall judge proper; and such Determination shall be final, binding, and conclusive to all Parties, to all Intents and Purposes whatsoever.

And be it further enacted, That where any Distress shall be made Distress not to for any Sum of Money to be levied by virtue of this Act, the Distress itself shall not be deemed unlawful, nor the Party or Parties making the form, fame be deemed a Trespasser or Trespassers on account of any Defect or want of Form in the Summons, Conviction, Warrant of Distress, or other Proceedings relating thereto, nor shall the Party or Parties distraining be deemed a Trespasser or Trespassers, ab initio, on account of any Irregularity which may or shall be afterwards done by the Party or Parties so distraining, but the Person or Persons aggrieved by such Irregularity shall and may recover full Satisfaction for the special Damage in an Action upon the Cafe.

and, to the Intent that the said Company of Proprietors might be enabled to carry on the said Undertaking, they were thereby empowered to raise and contribute amongst themselves, in such Proportions as to them should seem meet and convenient, a competent Sum of Money, to be divided into Shares of One hundred Pounds each, for making and completing the said Canal and other Works therein mentioned, not exceeding in V.due in the Whole the Sum of Forty-seven thousand seven hundred Pounds, except as therein and hereinafter mentioned; that is to say, that in case the said Sum of Forty-seven thousand seven hundred Pounds should be found inefficient for making, completing, and maintaining the said Canal, and other the Works thereby authorized to be made, and all necessary Charges and Expences relating thereto, then and in such Case it should be lawful for the said Company of Proprietors to raise and contribute among themselves, in Manner-and Form therein mentioned, and in such Shares and Proportions as to them should seem meet, or by the Admission of new Subscribers, any further or other Sum of Money for completing and perfecting the said Navigation, not exceeding the Sum of Twenty thousand Pounds; and the said Company of Proprietors were thereby also authorised to raise the said Sum of Twenty thousand Pounds, or any Part thereof, by Mortgage of the said Undertaking, in the Manner in the said Act mentioned: And whereas the said Company of Proprietors have expended in and for the Works and Purposes in the said Act mentioned, not only the said Sum of Fertv-seven thousand seven hundred Pounds, but also the said further Sum of Twenty thousand Pounds, which Sums (except some small Arrears thereof) have been raised by Contributions amongst themselves, under the Powers of the said recited Act; and there is also now due and owing, for the Purchase and Use of Lands and-Tenements, for Monies aiaised and expended in carrying on the necessary Works of the Navigation, and for other incidental Charges, the Sum of Thirty one thousand three hundred and forty-five Pounds: And whereas great Prog refs hath been made in and towards the Completion of the said Canal and Works in the said Act mentioned, but from various unforeseen Events the Money already raised and authorized to be raised by the said recited Act has been found very inadequate for the Purposes therein mentioned, and over and beftdes the said Sum of Thirty-one thoufaatT three hundred and fort .-five Pounds now due and owing as aforesaid, the further Sum of Forty-eight thousand six hundred and fifty-five Pounds will be necessary and is requisite to finish the said intended Canal, and the Works by the said recited Act authorized to be made, so as to render the said Navigation commodious and beneficial to the said Company of Proprietors, and of Utility to the Publick, which said Sums of Thirty-one thousand three hundred and forty-five Pounds, and Forty-eight thousand six hundred and fifty-five Pounds, make together the Sum of Eighty thousand Pounds: May it therefore pleale Your Majesty that it may be enacted; and be it enacted by the King’s most Excellent Majesty, by and with the Advice and Consent of the Lords Spiritual and Temporal, and Commons, in this present Parliament assembled, and by the Authority of the same, That it shall be lawful for the said Company of Proprietors, and they are hereby authorized to raise, pay, and contribute , *9 naongit

GEORGII III. REGIS.

Cap. 5.

An Act to enable the Company of Proprietors of the Surrey Iron Railway to raise a further Sum of Money, for completing the said Railway, and the Works thereunto belonging. [1 2th March 1805.3

WHEREAS by an Act passed in the Forty-first Year of the Reign of His present Majesty, for making and maintaining a Railway from the Town of JVandsworth to the Town of Croydon, with a Collateral Branch into the Parish of Carjbalton, and a navigable Communication between the River Thames and the said Railway at Wandsworth, all in the County of Surrey, several Persons therein named, and their Successors, are united and made one Body Politic and Corporate, by the Style or Name of “The Surrey Iron-Railway Company;” and are authorized to make and maintain the said Railway, and other Works in the said Act mentioned, and to raise any Sum of Money for defraying the Expence thereof, not exceeding Thirty-Five Thousand Pounds; but that in case the said Sum should not be found sufficient for carry ing the Purposes of the said Act into Execution, then the said Company of Proprietors were authorized and empowered to raise a further Sum of Money, not exceeding Fifteen Thousand Pounds, for perfecting and completing the said Railway and other Works: And whereas considerable Progress hath been made in carrying on the Works directed by the said Act, and in making the Purchales which by the said Act were authorized to be made, but from the great Advance in the Price of Materials and Labour, and from other Circumstances which have taken place ftnce the passing of the said Act, ic is found that the said Act cannot be carried into complete Execution without a Power being given to the said Company iLoc. {*? Per.] Si to

Cap. 6.

XIII. And be it further enacted, That if any Dispute shall happen about the Amount of the Tolls due, or the Charges of keeping any Distress, it shall be lawful for the Collector, or Person so distraining, to retain such Distress, or the Money arising from the Sale thereof, (as the Cafe may happen) till the Amount of the Tolls due, and the Charges of the Distress and Sale, and of keeping the Distress (as the Cafe may happen) be ascertained by some Justice of the Peace for the County or District in which the Cause of Dilpuce shall arise, who, upon Application made to him for that Purpose shall examine the Matter on the Oath of the Parties, or other Witness or Witnesses, and shall determine the Amount of the Tolls due, and also assess the Charges of such Distress and Sale, and of the Coiltdor’s Attendance for that Purpose upon the said Justice; all which Sums so determined or act (fed, shall be paid to the said Collector, before he shall be obliged to return the said Distress, or the Overplus after Sale thereof, or any Part thereof.

XIV. And be it further enacted, That in case any Dispute, Suit, or Litigation shall arise, touching or in any wise relating to the said Tolls, the Person or Persons appointed to collect the fame, or any other Person or Persons acting by or under the Authority of the said Trustees, shall be and are hereby declared not to be incompetent to give Evidence in any such Dispute, Suit, or Litigation, by reason of his, her, or their being so appointed to collect the said Tolls, or acting under the Authority of the said Trustees.

XV. And be it further enacted, That the Right and Property of all the Turnpikes and Toll Houses, and other Buildings to be erected or provided in or upon the said Roads, and of the Stone and Materials for building or repairing the fame, and also of all Stone and Materials got or collected for repairing the said Roads, shall be and are hereby veiled in the said Trustees, and they, or any Five or more of them, are hereby empowered to bring or cause to be brought any Action or Actions in the Name or Names of their Clerk or Clerks for the Time being, or to prefer or order the preferring of any Indictment or Indictments against any Person or Persons who shall injure the fame, or disturb them in the Possession thereof.

LXVIII. And be it further enacted, That this Act shall be deemed, adjudged, and taken to be a Publick Act, and be judicially taken Notice of as such by all Judges, Justices, and other Persons whomsoever, without specially pleading the same.

LXIX. And be it further enacted, That this Act shall commence and have Continuance from the Day on which the same shall receive the Royal Assent, and shall continue in force for and during the Term of Twenty-one Years, and from thence to the End of the then next Session of Parliament.

Cap. 8.

An Act for inclosing and draining certain Lands in the Parishes of Wviterton, EaJI Somerton, and W?Jl Somerton, in the County of Norfolk.

XLVII. And be it further enacted, That if any Person or Persons shall wilfully and maliciously cut, damage, break down, demolilb, or destroy any Bank, Mill, Engine, Dam, Floodgate, Bridge, Dike, Sluice, or Tunnel already made, or which shall at any Time hereafter be made or erected, supported, maintained, or used for the Purposes of this Act, every Person so offending and being convicted thereof shall be deemed guilty of Felony, and the Court before whom such Person shall be tried and convicted shall have Power and Authority to cause such Person or Persons to be punished in like Manner as Felor.s arc directed to be punished by the Laws and Statutes of this Realm, or, in Mitigation of such Punilhinenr, such Court may, if they think fit, award such Sentence as the Law directs in Cafes of Petit Larceny.

XLVIII. And be it further enacted, That if any Person or Persons shall wilfully or maliciously flop, dam up, or damage any Drain, Watercourse, Dam, Bridge, Stile, or other Work or Works which shall at any Time hereafter be making or erecting, or made or erected, supported, maintained, or used for the Purposes of this Adf, every Person so offending and being thereof convicted before any Two or more Justices of the Peace for the said County of Norfolk, on the Oath of One or more credible Witness or Witnesses, (which Oath such Justices are hereby authorized to administer), shall forfeit and pay any Sum not exceeding Fifty Pounds, to be levied by Distress and Sale of the Goods and Chattels of every such Offender by Warrant under the Hands and Seals of such Justices; and such Money when so levied shall be paid to any One or more of the said Special Commissioners, or to their Clerk, and shall be applied towards the Discharge of the Expences atrending the Execution of this Act; and for Want of sufficient Distress such Offender or Offenders shall by the said Justices be committed to the Common Gaol of the said County of Norfolk for any Time not exceeding Twelve Calendar Months, at the Difcreuor. of the said Justices.

ANNO QUADRAGESIMO QUINTO

GEORGII III. REGIS.

Cap. 9.

An Act for inclosing Lands in the Parish of Simonburn, in the County of Northumberland.

[12th March 1805.]

WHERERAS there is within the Parish of Simonbutn, in the County of Northumberland, a Common Moor or Waste, containing by Estimation Three thousand Acres or thereabouts. Part whereof isfcommonly called or known by the Name of E ling ham Rig Common, and the other Part thereof by the Name of Sbitlington Common: And whereas the Commissioners arrd Governors of the Royal Hospital for Seamen at Greenwich, in the County of Kent, are Lords of the Barony or Manor of Wark, in the County of Northumberland aforesaid, and as such claim to be seised of or entitled to the Soil and Inheritance, and the Mines, Minerals, Quarries, and Royalties of, within, and under the Whole of the said Common Moor or Waste, containing Three thousand Acres, as Part and Parcel of their said Barony or Manor of Wark: And whereas James Allgood Esquire claims to be Lord of the Manor of Sbitlington, in the said County of Northumberland, and as such claims to be seised of or entitled to the Soil and Inheritance of that Part of the said Common Moor or Waite, which is commonly called or known by the Name of Sbitlington Common, confiding of One thousand and fcvtn hundred Acres or thereabouts, and the Mines, Minerals, Quarries, and Royalties of, within, and under the fame; but which Claim of the said James Allgood is altogether denied by the said Commissioners and Governors; and which [Lc'c. £s? disputed Claim of the said James Allgood it is intended shall be tried and finally settled and determined under a feigned Ilfiue or feigned Issues, as herein-after is mentioned in that Behalf: And whereas the said James Allgood Esquire, and several other Persons, are seised and poffifEd of divers Messuages, Lands, Tenements, and Hereditaments within the said Parish of Simcnburn, and in resptft thereof, or as appendant, appurtenant, or belonging thereto, they or their Lessees, Farmers, or Tenants, are or claim to be entitled to Right of Common in and upon the said Common Moor or Waste, or upon some Part or Parts thereof respectively: And whereas the said Common Moor or Waste, in its present State, is of licde Use or Advantage, but considerable Parts thereof are capable of Cultivation and Improvement; and the several Persons entitled to such Right of Common as aforesaid, are desirous that the Whole of the said Common Moor or Waste, with the Consent of the said Commissioners and Governors, should be divided and allotted, by Commissioners in that Behalf to be appointed, amongst the said Commissioners and Governors, and the several Persons entitled to Right of Common thereon or otherwise interested therein; which Division will be advantageous to all the Parties interested therein respectively, and tend to the Improvement of their respective Estates; but the fame cannot beefs.sted without the Aid of Parian.ent: May it therefore please Your Majesty that it may been acted; and be it enacted by the King’s most Excellent Majesty, by and with the Advice and Consent of the Lords Spiritual and Temporal, and Commons, in this present Parliament assembled, and by the Authority of the same, That John Fryer, of the Town and County of Newcastle-upon Tyne, Gentleman, and John Bailey of Chillingbam, in the County of Northumberland, Gentleman, shall be and they are hereby appointed Commissioners for fetiing out, dividing, and allotting, the Whole of the said Common Moor or Waste, containing by Estimation Three thousand Acres or thereabouts, and for putiing this Act in Execution, in such Manner and subject to such Regu-TheProvisions lations as are herein-after contained, and with such of the Powers, and Ac^toextend *ut5je^ to fUt;h of t'1c Rules, Orders, Directions, Authorities, Regula-to 11.is Ae;. tions, Restrictions, and Provisions, contained in an Act, pa(Ted-in the Forty-first Year of the Reign of His present Majesty, intituled, An Act for consolidating in One Act, certain Provisions usually infcried in Acts of Inclosure, and for f tciiitating the Mode of proving the fvcral Fadls usually required on the pnjfing of such Acts, as are not controuled by or repugnant to any of the Clauses, Provisions, or Regulations contained in this Act. And, for the more effectually obviating and preventing any Incon- How Differ-venicnee or Delay which might other wise happen or be occasioned in the ences between Proceedings of the said Commissioners, by reason of any Difference in f,onmare to Opinion between them, touching or concerning any Matter or Thing in be settled, the Execution of this Act, or any Point or Points, Question or Questions arising out of or relating thereto; and the Determination of every such Person so to be appointed, to be expressed in Writing under his Hand, shall be and shall be taken and deemed by the said Commissioners as c >oclusive and binding upon them, as to all and every the Matters or Things, or Points or Questions so respectively referred to his Determintion as aforesaid, to the Intent that the said Commissioners may be thereby enabled to proceed in the Execution of this Act, and to make their General Award as hereinafter directed, notwithstanding any such D'ffcrence in Opinion between them as aforesaid; and every such Person so to be appointed for the Purpose aforesaid shall take and subscribe such or a similar Oath (to be administered by the said Commissioners, or One of them), as by the fa>d Act of the Forty-first Year of the present Reign is directed to be taken by Commissioners; and shall have and is hereby vested with the fame Powers and Aucopriues as by the said Act and this present Act are given to the Commissioners hereby appointed; but so nevertheless as that any such Person shall not be empowered to act for any other Purpose than the determining of such Matters as may be so. referred to him as aforesaid; An Act for inclosing Lands in the Parities of Rothbury and Rif don, in the County of Northumberland. [ i 2 th March 1805.]

WHEREAS there is within the Paddies of Rothbury and EiJ don, or the one of them, in the County of Northumberland, a Common Moor or Wade, called Tojfon Common otherwise Hepple Common, containing by Estimation Five thousand Acres or thereabouts: And whereas Sir John Bichanan, of Riddell in North Britain, Baronet, is Lord of the Barony or Manor of Hopewell, otherwise Hepple, otherwise Heppell, and as such is or claims to be seised of or entitled to the Soil and Inheritance, and the Mines, Minerals, Quarries, and Royalties, of, within, and under the fa>d Common Moor or Waste: And whereas the said Sir John Buchanan of Riddell. Thomas Clennell of Harbottle Castle in the County of Northumberland, Esquire, and several other Persons, are seised and possessed of divers Messuages, Lands, Tenements, and Hereditaments within the said Barony or Manor and Parishes, and in respect thereof, or as appendant, appurtenant, or belonging thereto, they or their Lessees, Farmers or Tenants, are or claim to be entitled to Right of Common in and upon the said Common Moor or Wade: And whereas the said Common Moor or Waste, in i s present State, is of little Use or Advantage, but corfi.ierable Parts rheteof are capable of Cultivation and Improvement, and the several Persons entitled to such Right of Common as aforesaid are w l ing and desirous that the said Common Moor or Waste, with the Coulrnt of the said [Loc. GEORGII III. REGIS.

Cap. ir.

An Act for enabling the Company of Proprietors of the Canal Navigation from Manchester to or near jljhton-under-Lyne and Oldham more effectually to provide for the Discharge of their Debts, and to complete the said Canal, and the Cuts and Works thereto belonging. [ 18th March 1805.]

and the said Company of Proprietors have borrowed and taken up at Interest, upon Mortgages of the Rates authorized to be raised by virtue of the said Acts in the Manner directed by the said last-mentioned Act, the Sum of Eight thousand six hundred and seventy-seven Pounds, in part of the Sum of Twenty thousand Pounds thereby authorized to be borrowed and taken up at Interest, and which Sum of Eight thousand six hundred and seventy-seven Pounds is still owing on such Mortgages; but the said Company of Proprietors have not hitherto been able to raise the Residue of the said Sum of Twenty thousand Pounds: And whereas the said Company of Proprietors have made great Progress in or towards the Completion of the said Canal, Cuts, and other Works, and have not only expended therein the Whole of the Money which they have been able to raise under and by virtue of the said recited Acts, but have also contrafted Debts to a large Amount which are now due and owing, and which they are at present unable to discharge; and it is expedient that the said Company of Proprietors should be authorized, not only to provide for the Discharge of their said Debts, but also that they should be enabled to finish and complete the Whole of the said Canal, Cuts, and other Works; and it is found that the Powers and Provisions of the aforesaid Acts are insufficient for that Purpose: May it therefore please Your Majesty that it may be enacted; and be it enacted by the

Cap. 12.

An Act for enabling the Company of Proprietors of the Peak Forest Canal more effectually to provide for the Discharge of their Debts, and to complete the said Canal, and the Cut, Railways, or Stone Roads and other Works thereof, [i 8 th March 1805.]

Cap. 14.

An Act for more effectually repairing and improving the Road from a Place called Nightingales, in the Township of Heath Charnock, to the Bridge at the West End of the Town of Bolton in the Moors, in the County Palatine of Lancaster, and other Roads therein mentioned. [5th April 1805.]

Goods and Chattels cannot be found to answer such Distress, then J’ucii Justice is hereby required, by Warrant or Warrants under his Hand anu Seal, to cause such Offender or Offenders to be apprehended and brought, before him the said Justice; and in case such Penalty or Penalties, and the Custs and Charges of such Proceedings as aforesaid, to be settled as aforesaid, shall not be forthwith and immediately paid, such Justice is hereby required forthwith to commit such Offender or Offenders to the House oF Correction in and for the said County, District, or Place, there to remain without Bail or Mainprize until the said Penalties, and fuel* Gast* and Charges as aforesaid, shall be paid, or until such Offender or Offenders shall have compounded for the lame with the said Trustees, and paiJTuch Composition Money, which Composition the said Truffcss.arc hereby emT poweicd to make and accept.

LXXI. And be it further enacted, That no Proceedings to be had touching the Conviction of any Offender against this Act, shall bequashed or vacated for Want of Form, or be removable by Certiorari, or any other Writ or Writs, or Procels, into any of His Majesty’s Courts of Record at Westminster or Lancaster; any Law or Statute to the contrary notwithstanding.

LXXII. And be it further enacted, That if any Action or Suit shall be commenced against any Person or Persons for any Thing done in pursuance of this Act, the same shall be commenced within Six Calendar Months next after the Offence committed, or Cause of Attion or Suit accrued, and not afterwards, and shall be laid and brought in the said County of Lancaster, and not elsewhere; and the Defendant and Defendants in such Action or Suit shall and may plead the General Issue, and give this Act and the special Matter iri Evidence at any Trial to be had thereupon, and that the fame was done in pursuance and by the Authority of this Act , and if it shall appear so to have been done, or that such Action or Suit shall be commenced after the Time before limited for bringing the fame, or shall be brought in any other County or Place, that then the Jury shall find for the Defendant or Defendants-, or if the Plaintiff or Plaintiffs shall be nonsuited, or discontinue his, her, or their Action or Suit, after the Defendant or' Defendants shall have appeared, or if upon Demurrer Judgement shall be given against the Plaintiff or Plaintiffs, the Defendant or Defendants shall and may have and recover Treble Costs, and have the like Remedy for the fame as any other Defendant or Defendants hath or have by Law in any other Cafe.

LXXIII. And be it further enacted, That the several and respeSive Persons who have subscribed Money for and towards making and repairing, and improving the Roads comprized in this Act, or any Part thereof, shall and are hereby re*quired to pay tl-e Sum or Sums to by them re-spefiively subscribed, in iuih Parts and Proportions, within such Time and Times, and to such Person and Persons, as the said Trullees, or any Five or more of them, shall by any Writing under their H inds authorize to receive the same; and if any Person or Persons shall negiect or refule to pay the lame in Manner aforesaid, it shall be lawful for the said Trustees, or any Five or more of them, to sue for and recover '.he fame, either in their own Names, or in the Name of the Clerk or Treasurer to the said Trullees, in His Majesty’s Court of Common Pleas for the County of Lancaster, by Action of Debt, or on the Cafe, or by Bill, Suit, or Information, wherein no Essoign, Protect.on. Wager of Law, or more than One Imparlance, shall be allowed.

LXXIV. And be it further enacted, That this Act shall be deemed and taken to be a Publick Act, and shall be jud daily taken Notice ot as such by all Judges, Justices, and others, without being specially pleaded.

GEORGII III. REGIS.

Cap. 16.

An Act for continuing the Term, and altering and enlarging the Powers of Two Acts passed in the Thirty-fourth and Thirty-seventh Years of His present Majesty, for making and repairing certain Roads in the Counties of Clackmatman and Perth; and for making and keeping in Repair several other Roads communicating the rewith.

£<jth April 1805.]

WHEREAS an Act was passed in the Thirty-fourth Year of Act 34 g. 3, the Reign of His present Majesty, intituled, “ An Act for recited.

“ making and repairing certain Roads in the Counties of Clackmannan and PerthAnd whereas another Act was passed in the Thirty-seventh Year of His present Majesty, intituled, “ An Act 37 Geo. 3.

" for altering and amending, and enlarging the Term and Powers of an “ Act, made in the Thirty-fourth Year of His present Majesty’s Reign for making and repairing certain Roads in the Counties of Claci- tnannan and Perth:” And whereas the Trustees appointed by the said Acts have borrowed considerable Sums of Money on their own personal Security, and on the Credit of the Tolls thereby granted, and bave made great Frogrefs in the Execution of the said Acts; but the said Roads cannot be effectually amended and kept in Repair, nor the ^loney so borrowed repaid, unless the Term of the said Acts be en-darged, the Tolls increased, and further and other Powers granted:

And whereas it would be of great Advantage to the Public if the Road, New Roadi. branching from the said Turnpike-Road at or near to the Distillery of Kilbagie, in the Parish of Clackmannan, and to be conducted in a Morth east Direction, by the Ealt End of Garjlang-Dam, through the Parish and County of Clatkmannan-, until it joins the Mew Turnpike-\Loc. 6? XXIV. And be it further enacted, That the said Trustees, or their Providing Contractors or Overseers, shall be, and are hereby empowered to provide {^Material* proper Places, at the Distance of One Furlong one from another, on

rhe Sides of the said Roads, as Repositories for Stone, Gravel, and other Materials, for making and repairing the said Roads, Damages being always paid for the Ground occupied by such Repositories, and the Fences and Inclosures properly repaired.

XXV. And be it further enacted, That if any Person or Persons shall PublicRoads graze, or allow their Horses, Cows, or other Cattle, to graze upon the and Foot-Sides or Parts of the said Roads, or in the Drains or Ditches adjoining pr°’ thereto; or shall ride upon the Footpaths constructed along the Sides

of the said Roads, or use the fame for any other Purpose whatever, than the Accommodation of Foot Passengers; or hang or place any Gate across the fame, or along the Side thereof, to open otherwise than into the Field; or build any Windmill, or Kiln for burning Lime or Bricks, within Twenty Yards of the Sides of any of the said Roads, every such Person or Persons shall, for every such Offence, forfeit and pay any Sum not less than Ten Shillings Sterling, nor exceeding Thirty Shillings Sterling; and shall, over and above, remove the Nuisance, and be liable to pay the whole Damage sustained by the Trustees.

XXVI. And be it further enacted, That from and after the passing of this Heritors, 4c. Act, if any Heritor or Occupier of Land on the Sides of the said Roads, rtPair shall make any Road, or Entry from the said Roads, into any Field or d0,etfv'hem Inclosure adjoining the fame, or shall alter any such Road, or Entry al- to the Roads, ready made, or which hereafter may be made, such Heritor or Occupier shall be obliged, within Twenty-four Hours after the fame may

be completed, to repair whatever Damage may have been done to the Road or Footpath by such Operations, and make proper Bridges or Conduits for venting the Water, so that it may not stagnate on the Road; and if he shall refuse, or neglect so to do, he shall, over and above, forfeit and pay not less than Forty Shillings Sterling, and not exceeding Five Pounds Sterling.

Provided always, and be it further enacted, That all Innkeep- Preventing ers, and other Persons, residing in any Houses adjoining to the said Obstrufliom Roads, shall provide proper and convenient Places for the Reception of onthcRoads. XXIX. And be it further enacted, That no Driver of any Waggon, Wain, Cart, Coach, Chaise, or other Carriage, Florfe, Afs, Mule, or other Bead of Burthen, whether the fame be loaded or unloaded, shall drive, or permit the fame to travel or pass upon the said Road, or any Part thereof, abreast or alongside of any other Waggon, Wain, Cart, Coach, Chaise,or other Carriage, Horse, Afs, Mule, or other Beast of Burthen, so as willfully to obstruct the free Passage of the said Roads, or any Part thereof; and that for every Waggon, Wain, Cart, or other Carriage, drawn by Two or more Horses, Oxen, or other Beasts of Draught, there shall be at lead One Driver; and that there shall be one Driver at the lead for every Two Waggons, Wains, Carts, or other Carriages, drawn by One Horse, Ox, or other Beast of Draught; and every Person or Persons offending in the Premises, shall forfeic and pay any Sum not exceeding Twenty Shillings Sterling, nor less than Five Shillings Sterling, for every such Offence.

XXX. And be it enacted, That the Driver of every Waggon, Wain, Cart, Coach, Chaise, or other Carriage, Horse, Afs, Mule, or other Beast of Burthen, travelling upon the said Roads, or any Part thereof, shall be obliged, upon meeting another Waggon, Wain, Cart, Coach, Chaise, or other Carriage, Horse, Afs, Mule, or other Beast of Burthen, to make Way, by holding, or driving to his own Left Hand, or what is commonly called, holding to his Near Side; and shall, upon passing any Waggon, Wain, Coach, Chaise, or other Carriage, Horse, Afs, Mule, or other Beast, be obliged to pass upon the Right Hand of such Carriage, Horse, or other Beast; and the Driver of every such Carriage, Horse, or other Beast, so to be passed, shall be obliged to hold or drive to his near Side, and that without Distinction whether the Carriage, Waggon, Wain, Coach, Chaise, Cart, or other Carriage, Horse, Afs, Mule, or other Beast of Burthen, so meeting or passing, are loaded or unloaded; and every Person offending in the Premiles, shall forfeit and pay any Sum not exceeding Twenty Shillings Sterling, nor less than Five Shillings Sterling, for ever such Offence.

XXXIX. And be it enacted, That the Charges and Expences of passing this Act shall and may, in the first Place, be paid out of the Monies raised or to be raised by virtue of the said former Acts, or this

present Act.

XL. And be it enacted, That the Tolls, Duties, and Powers, hereby granted and given, shall take place from and after the Third Tuef-day after the passing of this Act, and the Powers granted by the said recited Acts (except where hereby altered), and also this Act, shall have Continuance from thence, for and during the Space of Twenty-one Years, and from thence to the End of the then next Session of Parliament; and that this Act shall be deemed, and taken to be, a Public Act, and shall be judicially taken Notice of as such by all Judges, Justices, and others, without being specially pleaded.

1. The House belonging to and possessed by Mistress Margaret

Alexander, residing in Alloa, adjoining to her Dwelling-House on the North of the Road leading from Alloa to Cambus.

North Side of the Road leading from Alloa to Cambus, and belonging to and possessed by James Barr, Manufacturer in Alloa.

to and poficffed by James Younger, Brewer in Alloa.

Alloa, on the West of the Coalgate of Alloa.

the West Side of the Coalgate of Alloa.

An Act for repealing Three Acts, passed in the Twentieth, Twenty-second, and Twenty-sixth Years of the Reign of King George the Second, for repairing the Road from Stockton-upon-Tees to Darlington, and from thence to Barnardcafile, in the County of Durham; and for more cffedlually repairing the said Road. Cap. i8.

An Act for vesting certain Estates, situate in the Counties of Essex and Surrey, devised by the Will of Sir William Burrell Baronet, deceased, in Trustees, upon Trust, to sell the same; and for laying out the Money arising from the Sale thereof in the Purchase of Estates in the County of Sussex, to be settled to the same Uses as the Estates so fold.

Cap. 19.

An Act for inclodng Lands in the Parishes of Carlton, Chellington, and Steventon, in the County of Bedford. [5 th April 1805.]

WHEREAS there are certain Open and Common Fields, Common Meadows, Common Pastures, Commonable Lands, and Waste Grounds, lying and being within the several Parishes of Carlton, Chellington, and Steventon, in the County of Bedford: And whereas the Right Honourable Thomas Lord Viscount Hampden is Lord of the Manor of Chellington aforesaid, and Thomas Alston Esquire, is Lord of the frveral Manors of Carlton and Steventon aforesaid: And whereas the said Lord Viscount Hampden is Patron of the consolidated Redories of Carlton and Chellington aforesaid: And whereas the Reverend William Hooper, Clerk, is Rector of the consolidated Rtdorics of Carlton and Chellington, and as such is entitled to certain Glebe Lands and Right of Common, and to all the Great and Small Tythrs atifing, growing, renewing, or happening, within the said Patilhes oi Carlton and Chellington: And whereas the Molt Noble John Duke ot Bedford is Patron of the Vicarage of Steventon aforesaid, and the Reverend Thomas Orlebar Marsh, Clerk, is Vicar of the said Parish of Steventon, and as such is entitled to certain Glebe Lands and Right of Common, and to certain Vicarial or Small Tythes arising, growing, renewing, or happening, within the said Parish: And whereas QLw. £5* Per.} 4 T the

shall be final and conclusive to all Parties concerned, and shall not be subject or liable to be removed by Certiorari, or any other Writ or Process whatsoever, into any of His Majesty’s Courts of Record at Westminster or elsewhere.

Cap. 21.

An Act for regulating the Police of the City of Edinburgh^ and the adjoining Districts; and for other Purposes relating thereto. [10th Slpril 1805.]

WHEREAS, by the Extension of the City of Edinburgh, and the great Increase of Inhabitants therein, and in its Vicinity, it has become necessary to provide for a more steady and regular Administrarion of internal Government and Police within the same, and to establish more effectual Regulations for apprehending and punishing Vagrants and disorderly Persons, Suppreftion of Common Begging, removing Nuisances, lighting and cleaning the Streets and Passages, and, in general, for the Preservation of Peace and good Order within the said City and Places adjoining, and for the Comfort of the Inhabitants: And whereas it is expedient to veil the Lord Provost and Magi-itrates of Edinburgh with more ample Powers for licensing and making and enforcing Regulations and Fares for Ha. kney Coaches, Chairs, and Carts, and for Porters and Meters of Corn, as well in Edinburgh, as in the Port of Leith: And whereas the Inhabitants of the said City and PUces adjacent, are liable to great Impoficions in the Weight of Coals, Hay, Straw, and other Matters, brought into the fame, and it is proper [Loc. Per.2 5 E that

that such Abuses should be prevented and remedied: And whereas it is expedient that Regulations should be adopted, with respect to the Weight of Bread baked for Sale within the said City and Liberties and the Suburbs thereof, and brought from the Barts adjacent, and fold within the same; but the several Put pole* aforesaid cannot be effected without the Authority of Pjrliament: May it therefore plea lb Your Majesty that it may be enacted; and be it enacted by the King’s most Excellent Majesty, by and with the Advice and Consent of the Lords Spiritual and Tempera!, and Commons, in this present Parliament aflcrabled, and by the Authority of the same, That the Regulations herein-after made with respect to the Establishment of a General System of Police, and for cleansing and lighting the Streets and Passages, for apprehending and punishing Vagrants and disorderly Persons, suppressing common Begging, preventing Nuisances and Obstructions, and for other Purposes tending to the Preservation of Peace and good Order within the said City and Suburbs, and for imposing a Tax or AflefiTment for the Purposes aforesaid, shall extend over the Places following, videlicet, the City of Edinburgh, in- eluding the Extended Royalty, the Canongate, Pleafance, Colton, Saint Ninian’s Rout, North Back of the Canongate, Precincts of the Abbey of Holyroodhouse, Abbey Hill, Saint James’s Square, and adjacent Streets, Picaray, the F.after and Westci Roads to Leith, r© the Line of Boundary after mentioned, the Eight Districts to the South of the City, a* described in Two Acts passed in the Eleventh and Twenty-fifth Years of the Reign of His present Majesty, videlicet, the Street or Road leading from Brijlo Street, westward by Tiviol Row and Lawrieston to the Two-penny Custom, being One District, called the District of Tiviol Row and Lawrieston; XV. And be it enacted, That the First Meeting of the Resident Com- Meetings of missioners shall be at such Time as shall be determined by the General Com- commission-missioners, and shall be held at Twelve of the Clock Midday, at the Places ers. in the different DistriCts where the Elections are appointed to take place, or at any other Places to be directed by the General Commissioners; and Notice in Writing of the Time and Place of holding the First Meetings shall be sent to each Resident Commissioner by the Clerk to be appointed by the General Commissioners; and the said First Meetings may be adjourned from Time to Time, and to such Places as the Resident Commissioners present may think fit, until all necessary Directions and Appointments be given and made for carrying this Act into Execution as aforesaid; and the said Resident Commissioners shall hold their Meetings at such Hours and Places as they shall respectively appoint, upon the First Monday of November, to prepare Reports for the then ensuing Meeting of the General Commissioners, to be held upon the Third Monday of that Month; and they shall meet regularly, at such Hours and Places as they themselves shall appoint, upon the last Monday but one of April in every Year thereafter, to prepare a Report to the Meeting of the General Commissioners to be held in May following, wherein they shall describe the Situation of the Ward with respect to all Matters connected with the Objects of this Act, and suggest what may be proper to be attended to by the General Commissioners; and again upon the First Monday of November in every Year, to prepare a Report of the Progress made, and other Matters connected with this Act, to be laid before the Meeting of the General Commissioners to be held upon the Third Monday of that Month; and the Reports so made up shall be lodged with the Superintendant of Police in Manner following; the Reports made up in April, on or before the Fufl Monday of May, and the Reports made up upon the First Monday of November, on or before the Second Monday of that Month; at which Meetings the Resident Commissioners, behdes preparing the Repoits as aforesaid, shall take such other Steps, and give such Directions as may be necessary for the dfcCtual Execution of this Act; and at all such Meetings the Resident Commissioners shall have Power to adjourn to such Time as they shall think proper.

XVI. And be it enacted, That betides the Meetings herein-before speci* fied, occasional Meetings of the General and Resident Commissioners may be held, if found necessary; which occasional Meetings of the General Commifliuners shall be called by the Lord Provost as Prefes, or by any Three of the General Commissioners; and the Meetings of the Retident Commissioners shall be called by the Person whose Name shall Hand highest on the Lift as Prtfes of the Ward, or by any Two Rtfident Commis-fsoners , and Nutice in Writing shall be sent to every General Commissioner at least Forty-eight Hours before any Meetings of General Commit! sioners shall be held, and to every Resident Commissioner at least Twenty.four Hmrs before any Meetings of Resident Commissioners shall be held: Provided always, that at all the Meetings, whether of General or Resident Commissioners, the Commissioners present shall defray their own Expences.

XVII. And be it further enacted, That every Inspector shall, and he is hereby directed to distribute over the Ward committed to his Charge, the Officers of Police, Watchmen, and others, allowed by the General Commissioners, according to the Directions of the Resident Commissioners, if any such shall be-given; and he is hereby authorised to take the Charge of all Matters within the Lid Ward connected with the Objects of this Act, and shall also possess all the Powers given by the Law of Scotland to the Office of Constable; and, along with the Constables to be appointed as herein-after mentioned, and with the Officers of Police, Watchmen, and others aforesaid, shall assist in suppressing disorderly Houses, Mobs, and Riots, in extinguishing Fires, and preventing Danger of every K nd to the Lives and Properties of the Inhabitants, and shall apprehend and carry before the Superintendanc all Persons found transgressing against any of the Provisions of this Act, and all Persons detected in Disorders or Riots of any Kind, Assaults, Street Robberies, Hcufebreakings, Thefts, Refets of Thefts, Shoplifting, Depredations of every Kind by Servants or others under Trust, Picking Pockets, Swindling, and other Offences against Peace and good Order: And the said Inspector shall make a daily Report to the Superintendant of all Offences against this Act committed within his Ward, in so far as tire fame shall have come to his Knowledge; and shall also make up Lifts of the Inhabitants entitled to vote for Commissioners within the Ward, to be delivered ro the Resident Commissioners at least Six Days before the annual Elcdtion in the Month of dpril, and with respect to all Prosecutions for Offences committed within the respective Wards, and all Trials of Offenders residing the rein, under the Authority of this Act, the Inspector of the Ward shall be held as Procurator Fifcal therein; and in those Wards where Soldiers are in use to be quartered, the Inspector of the Ward shall be, and is hereby appointed Billet Master for the Ward or Bounds liable to be quartered on.

XVIII. XIX. And be it further enacted, That when the Superintendant Or Matter of Police is appointed by the General Commissioners, as before mentioned, His Majesty’s Sheriff Depute of the County of Edinburgh shall be, and is hereby authorized and required to grant to the said Superintendant, a Substitution of Sheriffship within the Bounds aforesaid, to the EfficCt of enabling him to grant Warrants against Offenders, and to act as a Judge or Magistrate in the Execution of his Duty under this Act: And the said Superintendant, after he shall receive a Substitution from the Sheriff Depute, as aforesaid, shall have full Power to act as a Sheriff Substitute accordingly, in all Matters and Things falling under the Authorities given by this Act.

ANNO QUADRAGESIMO QUINTO

GEORGII III. REGIS.

An Act for making and maintaining a Road leading from the Limits of the Counties of Edinburgh and Lanark to the Burgh of Lanark in the County of

WHEREAS the making and maintaining a Road beginning at the Limits of the Counties of Edinburgh and Lanark, near Wood-muir, in the County of Edinburgh, and running Westward from the said Limits through the County of Lanark, by or near the Town of IVtlfontown, through the Forth* to Clegborn Bridge, and onwards to the Burgh of Lanark, all in the Parishes of Carnwath, CarJiairs, and Lanark, in the said County of Lanark , and also a Branch or Line from the said Road towards Ravenjtruther, in the Parish of Carjtairs and County of Lanark aforesaid, would be of great Benefit to the Public, but the fame Can tot be eff, dually made, maintained, and kept in Repair by the Funds and Means provided and prescribed by the Laws now in force, nor unless further Powers are given and Regulations made for that Purpose by Authority of Parliament: May it therefore plrafe Your Majesty that it may be enacted; and be it enacted by the King’s most Excellent Majesty, by and with the Advice and Consent of the Lords Spiritual and Temporal, and Commons, in this present Parliament assembled, and by the Authority of the same, That the most Honourable Alexander Hamilton, T.ufttes, commonly called Marquis of Douglas and Clydesdale, George Fergufon of Hertnand, one of the Senators of the College of Justice, Sir William

VIII. And be it enacted, That the said Trustees shall be, and they art hereby empowered to diminish or lessen all or any of the said Rates, upon the frid Roads, or any Part thereof, with the Consent of the Person* entitled to Five-Sixths of the Money then due and owing on the Credit

An Act for amending an Act, passed in the Thirty-seventh Year of His present Majesty, to amend and render more effectual an Act, made in the Thirty-first Year of His late Majesty, for the due making of Bread, and to regulate the Price and Aftize thereof, and to punish Persons who shall adulterate Meal, Flour, or Bread, so far as the fame relates to the Aftize and making of Bread, to be sold in the City of Lonaon and the Liberties thereof, and within the Weekly Bills of Mortality, and Ten Miles of the Royal Exchange. GEORGII III. REGIS.

Cap. 24.

An Act to enable Robert Bowyer of Pall Mall, in the City of Wiestminster, Esquire, to dispose of his Collection of Paintings, Drawings, and Engravings, together with several Copies of certain Books therein mentioned, by way of Chance.

[1 ith April 1805.]

WHEREAS Robert Bowyer, of Pall Mall, in the City of Westminster, Esquire, duting the Peace of the Year One thousand seven hundred and eighty-three, amidst the Publication of other Works of Art in which lie was then engaged, conceived a Plan for promoting and bringing to Perfection the Arts of Painting and Engraving in this Country , and not doubting to receive Afiitlance from various Sources in the Pmfecution of it, did, in order to the maturing rhereof, rel'olve to publish some splendid Work in which the most per-ftdt Specimens of Engraving from Paintings by Artilts of this Country ftould be exhibited, and which mighr eventually prove a National Concern and Honour: And whereas, in furiher pursuance of this laudable Design, the said Robert Bowyer has, at a very considerable Expence during several Yeats past, formed a most valuable Collection of Paintings, Drawings, and Engravings, by Artists of this Country, winch Iras been for frveral Years publickly exhibited in Pall Mall under the Name of The Hijloric Gallery, and the said Robert Bowyer has, betides various other Works, proceeded to publish, and hath nearly completed, a mott splendid E i t’on of Hurr.e's Htjlory cf England, ornamented with Engravings from [Ltc. fc? GEORGII III REGIS.

An Act for assessing the Proprietors of Lands in the County of Sutherland\ towards the Expence of making and supporting such Roads and Bridges therein, as shall be approved of by the Commissioners appointed by an Act of the Forty-third Year of His present Majesty, for making Roads and building Bridges in the Highlands of Scotland \ for making a Turnpike Road from Portinleik to the Ord; and converting the Statute Labour of the said County into

present Majesty’s Reign, intituled, An Act for granting to His 43 G.3.C. So. VIII. And be it enacted, That a Copy of the Resolution of every such Meeting, requiring an Assessment to be made for the Purposes of this Act, shall forthwith be transmitted by the Prefes, or failing him, by any Three Members of the Meeting at which the same shall have been made, to the Convener of the Commissioners of Supply of the said County of Sutherland; and thereupon the Commissioners of Supply of the said County shall be summoned to meet and assemble within Twenty Days thereafter; and being met and assembled, they shall make an Assessment upon each and every Proprietor, Life-renter, or proper Wad-fetter of Land enjoying the Dominium utile thereof in the said County, to the Amount of the Sum specified in such Resolution to be levied in conformity to the Terms therein specified.

IX. And be it further enacted, That every Assessment made by virtue of this Act, and each and every Part and Portion thereof, shall be levied and recovered by the Collector of the Land Tax of the said County, in the same Manner as the Land Tax is or may be levied or recovered; and fitch and the like Remedies, Powers, Penalties and Forfeitures, are hereby given for the Payment and Recovery of every such Assessment, which are given or may be applied and enforced for the Payment and Recovery of the Land Tax: Provided always, that every such Collector shall find Security for his faithful and true accounting for and paying as herein directed, all Monies to be received by him pursuant to this Act, in the same Manner that such Collector does for his faithful and true accounting for and paying all Sums of Money received by him as Collector of the Land Tax.

LIII. And be it enacted, That if any Heritor, in any Parish, shall offer to advance Money for making any Road standing, for the Time, first in the Specification among the new Roads to be made in such Parish, the said Justices may, and they are hereby empowered, to agree to such Proposal, and to direct the Application of such Money accordingly, and to grant to such Heritor, Two-Thirds of the free Annual Fund to arise in the said Parish from the Conveifion of the Statute Labour, until he shall be reimbursed for such Advance; but no such Grant shall extend beyond Seven Years.

LV. And be it further enacted, That it shall and may be lawful for the said Justices assembled ac any General Meeting, to exempt and free from the Performance of Statute Work, or the Payment of any Composition, all such Persons as shall appear to them to be in indigent Circumstances, and unable to pay the fame.

LVI. And be it enacted, That the Clerk of the Peace shall immediately after the aforesaid Accounts of the Conversion of the Statute Labour shall in each Year have been approved or rectified by the said Justices at their General Meeting aforesaid, deliver over the fame to the Clerk of the said Trustees, who shall be bound, before the P'irst Day of June in each Year, to engross in a Book to be kept for thac Use a full and accurate Copy thereof, and also of the Accounts which shall at the preceding Meetings in the Month of April, have been rendered by the Collector of the Land Tax, and by the Treasurer appointed by the Trustees in pursuance of this Act; and the said Book shall at all reasonable Times be open for Inspection, without Fee or Reward, to any Justice of the Peace or Freeholder of the said County, or to any Heritor, Life-renter, or proper Wadfetter in Possession of Lands therein valued, as aforesaid, at One hundred Pounds Scots or upwards.

LVII. And be it enacted, That when any Road shall be made, or marked out to be made, by virtue of this or the said recited Act, purfuamt to Resolutions of the Commissioners appointed by the said recited Act, or by virtue of this Act, under the Authority of the said Justices of the Peace, it shall not be lawful for any Person or Persons to build any House, or to make any Fence or Inclosure, or to plant any Trees within Twenty-live Feet of the Centre of the said Roads , and if any Person shall act in the contrary, all such Houses, Inclosures, and Plantations, may be destroyed and demolished, if they encroach upon the Road as actually made; and, if otherwise, no greater Allowance or Compensation lha'1 be made on account of the Road being afterwards widened, than would have been due if such Buildings, Fences, or Plantations had not been made.

An Act for continuing the Term, and altering and enlarging the Powers of Two Acts, passed in the Second and Twenty-fourth Years of His present Majesty, for repairing the Roads from Kirkby Steven High Lane Head, in the County of Westmorland, through Sedbergh to Greeta Bridge, in the County Palatine of Lancaster, and other Roads therein mentioned in the said Counties, and in the County of York. ANNO QUADRAGESIMO QUINTO

Cap. 28.

An Act for altering, amending, and consolidating several Acts for repairing Turnpike Roads in the County of Ayr; for repairing other Roads therein; and for making more effectual the Statute Labour in the said County. [t7th May 1805.]

and be it enacted by the King’s most Excellent Majesty, by and with the Advice and Consent of the Lords Spiritual and Temporal, and Commons, in this present Parliament artem. bled, and by the Authority of the same, That, from and after the Twenty seventh Day of May, One thousand eight hundred and five, the said recited Acts of the Seventh and Fourteenth Years of His present Majesty’s Reign shall be, and the fame are hereby repealed; VIII. LXXI. And be it enacted.That if any Person, liable as above, shall,refuse or neglect, on or before the said respective Days, to pay the aforesaid Conversion, it shall be lawful for the Justices of the Peace of the said County, or any one or more of the said Justices, to grant summary Warrants for poinding the Effects of the Defaulters, for Payment of the converted Values before mentioned, and a third Part more, besides the Expence ot Execution; which Warrants shall be granted, and the Just te- aforesaid are hereby required to grant the fame, upon an Application made by the Collector, and an Arteftation signed by him, bearing that the Persons complained of had been deficient in paying the Conversion above mentioned.

LXXII. Provided always, and it is hereby expressly provided and declared, That it shall and may be lawful for the Justices of the Peace aforesaid, or any one or more of them, to award Damages, to the Treble Value, to be paid to the Persons aggrieved by such Warrant or Warrants, by the Collector, if they shall find that the Collector has made a false and improper Accusation of any Person liable as aforesaid.

LXXIII. Provided always, That all Arrears of Conversion Money, or Toll Duties, Penalties, Forfeitures, and other Sums leviable under the aforesaid former Statutes of the Seventh and Fourteenth of His present Majesty, shall, notwithstanding the Repeal of these Acts, continue to be due and leviable according to the Regulations, Enactments, and Provi* Sons of these former Acts.

And be it enacted, That if the said Trustees, or any Seven or more of them, at any of their General Meetings, shall determine any Matter or Thing hereby committed to them, it shall not be in the Power of any fub* sequent Meeting to alter, vary, or annul, such Determination, or to give any Orders contrary and in Opposition to the Orders formerly given, un-lcfs such General Meeting shall be called upon Fourteen Days previous

LXXVIII. Provided alway', That it shall be noObjedion to any Person, acting as a Justice of the Peace in any Matter or Thing relative to this Act, that he is thereby appointed aTrustee.

LXXIX. Provided also, That no Complaint shall be competent in any Cafe whatsoever, after Six Calendar Months from the passing of any Order, Sentence, or Judgment, herein-before declared appealable.

LXXX. And be it enrded, That all Actions or Complaints for all and every the Penalties or Forfeitures imposed by this Act, or for any Wrongs done or Injuries suffered in any Matter relative thereto, or in consequence of any of the Powers by this Act given and granted, shall be commenced within the Space of Six Calendar Months after the Penalty or Forfeiture is incurred, or Wrong done, or Injury suffered, and not afterwards.

LXXXI.And be it enacted, That thejudgements and Sentencesof the Justices of the Peace of the said County, at their Quarter Sessions assembled,

LXXXII. And be it further enacted, That it shall and may be lawful to and for the saidTrustees of the Roads, along with the CommissionersofSup-plyfor the said County, at the annual Meeting for assessing the Land Tax, on the Thirtieth Day of April inTime coming, to afi'efs the wholeCounty in a Sum not exceeding Five Shillings Sterling upon every One hundred Pounds Scots of valued Rent yearly, as the Lands stand valued in the Cess Books of the said County, or shall be valued in Manner aforesaid, in lieu of the Assessment authorized by the Sixteenth Act of the Second Parliament of King Charles the Second herein-before recited; the Lands in the Paril'nes of Ayr and Irvine not valued, being assessed at the Rate of Five Shillings Sterling for every One hundred Pounds Sterling of real Rent; to be levied by the Collector of Supply at the fame Time with the Land Tax of the said County, and applied towards building, making, repairing, and upholding the Bridges in the said County, where the said Trustees shall direct.

LXXXIII. And be it enacted, that the Expence of passing this Act shall be defrayed and levied by an Assessmeny, which the said Trustees are hereby authorized to impose upon the Heritors or Land Owners within the said County of Ayr, according to the Valuation of their respective Lands, the unvalued Lands in the Parishes of Ayr and Irvine pay ing in the Proportion of One hundred Pounds Sterling of real Rent, to One hundred Pounds Scots of Valuation.

LXXXIV. And be it enacted, That this Act shall be deemed a Publick Act, and shall be judicially taken Notice of by all Judges, Justices, and others whomsoever, without specially pleading the same.

LXXXV. And be it further enacted.That this Act shall commence upon the Twenty-seventh Day of MayOne thousand eight hundred and five, and shall remain in force during the Term of Twenty-one Years, and from thence to the End of the then next Session of Parliament.

Cap. 30.

An Act for erecting and maintaining a Harbour, Docks, and other Works, at MrdroJfany in the County of Ayr. [17th May 1805.J

WHEREAS there is a Promontory or Point, called Ardrojfan, in the Parish of Ardrojfan, in the County of Ayr, terminated by a Ridge of Rocks, stretching for a considerable Way into the Sea fn a North-well Direction, immediately opposite to which, at the Diltance of about Half a Mile to the North-well, there is an Island called The Horse Isle, stretching nearly in a North and South Direction, which Promontory and Ridge of Rocks on the cine Side, and the said 1112nd oh the other, completely protest a capacious Bay formed between them from the Winds and Storms: And whereas there is a Depth of Water to the Extent of about Thirty Feet at low Water in ordinary Spring Tides, between the Extremity of the said Ridge of Rocks towards the Sea and the said Island being the Entrance to the said Bay, and within the same there is a Depth of from Twelve to Eighteen Feet at low Water in ordinary Spring Tides, with good Anchorage Ground, and the Tide rises to the Height of about Ten Feet in ordinary Spring Tides, and Seven Feet at Neap Tides: And whereas the said Bay may be formed into a safe and commodious Harbour, which may be entered at all Times of the Tide, and with any Wind, by Vessels of the larged Burthen, by construfting Piers upon the said Ridge of Rocks, whereby a safe and commodious [Lee. id Per.] 7 C Station

V. Provided always, and be it further enacted, That after any Call of Money shall be made upon the Proprietor or Proprietors of any such Share or Shares, in Manner herein directed, it shall not be in the Power of such Proprietor or Proprietors to fell or transfer any Share which he, she, or they may have in the joint Stock of the said Company, until the Monies called for upon such Share or Shares shall be paid; and airy Proprietor or Proprietors attempting to make such Sale or Transfer before paying such Monies so called for, shall forfeit every such Share or Shares, and all the Benefit and Profits thereof, and all such Shares so forfeited shall be veiled in the said Company of Proprietors, in Trust for and for the Benefit of the rest of the said Proprietors, in Proportion to their respective Interests in the said Undertaking.

VI. And be it further enacted, That the said Company of Proprietors shall and they are hereby required to cause the Names and Designations of the several Persons who shall be entitled to the Shares in the said Undertaking, with the Number of the Shares, and also the proper Number by which every Share shall be distinguished, to be fairly and distindly entered in a Book to be kept by their Clerk, and after such Entry to cause the fame to be signed by their Prefes; and they shall also cause a Certificate so signed by the Prefes and Clerk to be delivered to every Proprietor upon Demand, specifying the Share or Shares to which lie or (he is entitled in the said Undertaking, and such Certificate shall be admitted in all Courts whatever as Evidence of the Title of such Proprietor, his or her Executors, Administrators, and Assigns, to the Share or Shares therein specified; but the Want of such Certificate shall not hinder or prevent the Owner of any of the said Shares from felling or disposing thereof.

XIII. And be it further enacted, That the said Company of Proprietor*

shall assemble on the Twenty-first Day of June One thousand eight hundred and five, at Saltcoats, between the Hours of Twelve and One for the Purpose of putting this Act in Execution; and shall afterwards, on the First Friday in the Month of July In each and every Tear, assemble at such Place and at such Hour within Ten Miles of this said Harbour as the said Company of Proprietors shall at any General Meeting appoint; and in case no Place or Hour shall have been so appointed, then such General Meeting shall be holden where the lad General Meeting was holden; and such General Meetings shall have Power to adjourn themselves from Time to Time, as to the Majority of Proprietors present at such Meetings shall appear proper and convenient.

XV. And be it further enacted, That the said Company of Proprietors at their respective Meetings shall and may appoint a Prefes or Chairman, and such Prefes or Chairman shall not only vote as a Proprietor or Proxy, but in case of an Equality of Votes shall have the decisive or calling Vote.

and the said Committee shall, by themselves or their Clerk, keep a full and true Account of all Money disbursed and Payments made by the said Committee, and by all and every Person and Persons employed by or under them; and shall regularly, by themselves. or their Clerk, write, insert, and enter in a Book or Books, to be from Time to Time provided at the Expence of the said Company of Proprietors for that Purpose, Notes, Minutes, or Copies (as the Cafe shall require) of every such Contract, Bargain, Receipt, or Disbursement, and of all other their Orders and Proceedings, which Book or Books shall be deposited with and kept under the Care and Direction of the said Committee: Provided always, that every Proprietor shall have free Access thereto, as herein-before mentioned, for his or her Inspection; and the said Committee shall have Power from Time to Time to make such Call or Calls of Money from the Subscribers to and Proprietors of the said Undertaking, to defray the Expence of, or to carry on the fame, as they shall from Time to Time find wanting and necessary for those Purposes, so that no such Call shall exceed the Sum of Ten Pounds for every One hundred Pounds, and so in Proportion for any greater or less Share or Iuterefl which any Person or Persons shall and may be possessed of or entitled unto in the said Undertaking; LI. Provided always, and be it enacted, That it shall and may be lawful for the said Company of Proprietors or their Committee of Management, to receive and accept of and from any Mailer, Commander, or Owner of any Ship or Vessel, Bark or Boat, not exceeding the Burthen of One hundred and fifty Tons, trading to and from and fifing the said Harbour, such Composition for the said Rates and Duties, l.ut not exceeding the fame, and payable at such Times and in such Manner as shall be agreed upon by and between the said Company of Proprietors or their Committee of Management, and any such Master, Commander, cr Owner.

LII. Provided also, and be it further enacted, That all Ships and other Vessels belonging to or employed in the Service of His Majesty, using the said Harbour, shall be exempted from the Payment of all and every the Rates and Duties hereby granted for and upon Vessels using the fame.

LIII. Provided also, and be it further enacted, That if any Goods, Wares, or Merchandize, which have paid the above-mentioned Dues at unloading, shall be again exported in the fame Packages, they shall be exempted from the Payment of those Dues at re-shipping; and that no Fishery Salt imported in Bulk, and which shall be re-shipped in the Calks for the Fishery, shall ‘ be liable to the Payment of auy of the said Rates and Duties when so re-shipped, other than the Duty in the said Table flipu-lated for the Calks containing the fame, according to their Dimensions; and that no Ship or Vessel carrying Stones, Wood, or other Materials into the said Harbour, for the Use of the Piers or any other Works authorized to be made by virtue of this Act, shall be liable to the Payment of any of the aforei'aid Rates or Duties in respect of such Voyage or Goods.

LIV. And be it further enacted, That it shall be lawful for the said Company of Proprietors to ascertain and fix such reasonable Rates and Duties to be paid upon the loading or unloading, exporting or importing of any Article or Commodity not specified or enumerated in the said Table or Schedule to this Act annexed, in Proportion.to the several Rates and Duties therein specified, as they shall think fit, not exceeding the Sum of One Penny Halfpenny for every Shilling of the Freight thereof; which Rates and Duties, when so fixed and ascertained by the said Proprietors, shall be considered, to all Intents and Purposes, as if the fame had been especially enumerated in this Act, or in the said Table or Schedule hereunto annexed.

I.V. And be it further enacted, That it shall and may be lawful for the said Company of Proprietors, and such Person or Persons as they shall appoint, to ask, demand, and take, to and for their own proper Use and Behoof, of and from every Maiter and Owner of any Ship or Vessel graved or repaired in the said Graving Dock, for the Use thereof the Sum of Three Pence for each Ton of the Burthen of such Ship or Vessel for each Tide that such Ship or Vessel shall remain in the said Graving Dock.

LXI. And be it further enacted, That if any Goods, Warfes, Merchandize, Commodities, or other Matters or Things whatsoevcf, shall lie or remain upon any Wharf or Wharfs, Quay or Quays, Warehouse or Warehouses, belonging to the said Company, for above the Space of Twenty-four Honrs, then and in such Case the said Company, or such Person or Persons as they shall appoint, shall be entitled to receive such reasonable Rates or Allowances over and above the Rates and Duties herein-before authorized to be taken, as shall be agreed upon between the said Company, or their Agent or Agents, and the Proprietor or Proprietors of such Goods, Wares, Merchandize, or other Things.

And be it further enacted, That no Ship, Bark, Lighter, Boat, dr other Vessel, which shall be laid up as unfit for further Sea Service, or neglected by the Owner or Owners thereof, shall be permitted to be and remain in the said Harbour, or in any of the Docks or Basons to be made by virtue of this Act near to the Quays or Piers'thereof, but that in every such Case it shall and may be lawful to and for the said Company of Proprietors, or such Person or Persons as they shall appoint, to cause such Ship, Bark, Boat, or other Vessel so unserviceable, or neglected to be, at the Expence of the Owner or Owners of the fame, removed from the said Piers and Quays, or any of them, to another Part or Place of Safety within the said Harbour; and in case of Refusal or Neglect of Payment of such Charges and Expences by such Owner or Owners, Master, or Agents, of such Ship or other Vessel for the Space of Five Days after Demand shall be made, then and in every such Case it shall and may be lawful to and for the said Company, or any Person or Persons to be appointed by them, to levy such Expences by Distress and Sale of such Ship or other Vessel, or any of her Tackling, Apparel, or Furniture, or any Part thereof, rendering the Overplus, if any be (after deducting the Charges of such Distress and Sale) to the Owner or Owners, Master, Factor, or Agent of such Ship or other Vessel, whenever the same shall be demanded.

LXV. And be it further enacted, That it shall not be lawful to nor in the Power of any Person or Persons w ho shall have landed and caused to be landed any Goods or Merchandize, Timber, Wood of any Kind, Maffs, Yards, Pumps, Boats, Anchors, Cables, Calks, Guns, Ballast, Paving Stones, Lime Stones, Slates, Soapers Waffe, Dung or Manure, or any other Thing, (other than Materials for the necessary Repairs of the PieM, Quays, and for immediate Use in Shipping), upon any of the Piers and Quays, or Landing Places within the said Harbour, Docks, or Basons, or in any of the Avenues leading to the said Quays and Piers, or any of them, to continue or permit the fame to remain and lie thereon for any longer Time than Forty-eight Hours; and in all such Cases where the said Goods, or others aforesaid, shall have so continued beyond the Space of Forty-eight Hours, it shall and may be lawful to and for the said Company of Proprietors, or any Person or Persons appointed by them, to remove, or cause to be removed, all such Goods and other Things as they shall find so lying, continuing, and being on the said Piers, Quays, and other Places, above the said limited Time, to some Place or Places of Safety, and therein to detain and keep the fame till Payment of the Charges of such Removal and Detention, and if such Charges and Expences shall not be paid within the Space of Five Days after Demand thereof by the said Company, or some Person or Persons to be employed by them, then and in all such Cases they are hereby authorised to levy the same by Distress and Sale of the said Goods and FtFefts so respectively secured, and to render the Overplus, if any be, to the Owner or Owners, (the Charges of taking, keeping, and making Sale of such Distress being lirft deduced), on the fame being demanded.

LXIX. And be it enacted, That, from and after the passing of this Act, it shall not be lawful to any Person or Persons to throw dr empty any Ballad, Dud, Allies, or Rubbish, Shingle Stones, or other Things, into the said Harbour, or into the Entrance thereto, or the said Docks or Basons, or the Entrances thereto, or to dig and take away any Ballad, Shingle Stones, or other Things therefrom, to the Hurt and Prejudice of the said Harbour, Docks,* or Basons, or of the Works connected therewith, under a Penalty of not lefts than Five Pounds nor more than Ten Pounds for every such Offences besides raking up and removing all such Ballad, Dud, Allies, Rubbish, Shingle Stones, and other Things, and repairing the Damage occasioned by such Default, which the said Company of Proprietors are hereby empowered to do at the Expence of the Defaulter or Defaulters.

LXXXf.And be it further enacted, That any Person or Persons thinking themselves aggrieved by any Order or Judgment made or given in pursuance of any Rule, Bye-law, or Order of the said Company of Proprietors, or by any Order, Judgement, or Determination of any Justice or Justices of the Peace, relating to any Matter or Thing in this Act mentioned or contained, may, within Six Calendar Months next after such Order, Judgment, or Determination, shall have been made or given, (first giving Thirty Days Notice of such Complaint to the Person or Persons against whom such Complaint is intended to be made), complain to the Justices of the Peace at the General Quarter Sessions, to be held in and for the County in which the Cause of Appeal shall arise, who shall in a summary Way either hear and determine the said Complaint at such General Quarter Sessions, or if they think proper may adjourn the Hearing thereof to the next General Quarter Sessions of the Peace to be held for such County, and the said Justices may, if they fee Cause, mitigate any Forfeiture or Fine, and may order any Money to be returned which shall have been levied in pursuance of such Rule, Bye-law', Order, or Determination, and may also order and award such further Satisfaction to be made to the Party injured as they shall judge reasonable; and no Proceedings to be had and taken in pursuance of this Act shall be quashed or vacated for Want of Form, or be removed by Advocation, or by any other Process whatsoever, to the Court of Session, any Law or Statute to the contrary notwithstanding.

and if the same shall appear so to be done, or if such Action and Suit shall be brought after the Time herein-before limited for bringing the fame, or shall be brought without Thirty Days Notice thereof, or after a sufficient Satisfaction made or tendered as aforesaid, that then the Defender or Dt fenders shall be afibilzied; or if the Action shall be found irrelevant, or be otherwise dismissed, or the Pursuer shall not prosecute the Action, or suffer the fame to fall asleep, or if Judgement shall be given again It the Pursuer or Pursuers, the Defender or Defenders shall have Double Caffs, and shall have such Remedy for recovering the fame as any Defender or Defenders hath or have for Costs of Suit in any other Cafes of Law.

LXXXIII. And be it further enacted, That this Act shall be deemed and taken to be a publick Act, and shall be judicially taken Notice of as such by. all Judges, Justices, and others without being specially pleaded.
