And be it further enacted, That the said Trustees may and they are hereby empowered, by Writing under their Hands, to appoint a Treasurer or Treasurers, Cletk or Clerks, and a Collector or Collectors of the Tolls, and a Surveyor or Surveyors of the said Road, and also such other Officers and Persons for the Execution of this Act, as they the said Trustees shall think proper, and fiom Time to Time to make such Rules, Orders, and Regulations for the good Conduct and well governing of every such Treasurer, Clerk, Collector, Surveyor, and all such other Officers and Persons; And be it further enacted, That if any Person or Persons whomever shall remove or take away any Stones or Gravel, or other Materials laid upon the said Road, for the Repair thereof, without the Order of the said Trustees, or of their Surveyor or Surveyors for that Purpose, or if any Person or Persons whosoever shall take away any Stones or Gravel, or Materials which shall have been dug or gathered by or by the Order of the said Trustees, or their Surveyor or Surveyors, in any Lands, Fields, Grounds, River, or Brook, for the Purpose of amending the said Road, or any Part or Parts thereof, or shall get or take away any Stones or Gravel, or Materials out of any Pit or Quarry, which shall have been made for the Purpose of getting such Materials for amending the said Road, or any Part or Parts thereof, before the said Surveyor or Surveyors, or his or their Workmen, shall have discontinued working therein for the Space of Six Weeks (except the Owner or Occupier of any private Ground, and Persons authorized by such Owner or Occupier to get Materials therein for his or her own private Use only, and not for Sale) every Person so offending shall forfeit for every such Offence any Sum not exceeding Forty Shillings.

LVI. And be it further enacted, That if any Person shall hale or draw, or cause to be haled or drawn, upon any Part of the said Road, any Tree or Piece of I imber, or any Stone, otherwise than upon a Wheel Carriage, or shall suffer any Part of any Tree or Piece of s imber which shall be conveyed upon any Wheel Carriage, to drag upon any Part of such Road to the Prejudice thereof, every such Person shall for every such Offence forfeit and pay any Sum not exceeding Five Pounds nor less than Forty Shillings.

LVII. And be it further enacted, That the said Trustees shall and may cause the said Road to be measured, and Mile Stones to be set up at or near the Sides thereof, at the Distance of One Mile from each other, and Polls to be erected to denote the Distance of every such Post from any Town or Place, as the said Trustees shall think fit, and also cause to be erected Guide Posts upon such Parts of the said Road where the fame are crossed or joined by other Roads, and also Tables of the Tolls at each Turnpike Gate, as they shall judge proper; and if any Person or Persons shall wilfully break, throw down, injure, destroy, obliterate, or deface any Mile Stone, Table of Tolls, or Poll erected or to be erected on any Part of the said Road, or any of the Letters, Figures, or Marks infciibed thereon, or shall wilfully break, throw down, or injure any Scone or Stones, or Parapet Wail or Walls on the Side or Sides of any Bridge or Bridges, Arch or Arches, on any Part or Parts of the said Road, every such Person shall forfeit and pay any Sum not exceeding Five Pounds for each Stone, Table of Tolls, Poll, or Parapet Wall so broken, thrown down, injured, or deflroved, or on which any Letters, Figures, or Marks shall be so obliterated or defaced, One Moiety whereof shall go to the Informer, and the other Moiety shall be applied for the Purposes of this Act.

LXIV. And be it further enacted, That all Penalties or Forfeitures by Recover* ami virtue of this Act imposed, (the Manner of levying and recovering whereof is not hereby otherwise particularly directed) shall be levied and recovered by Distress and Sale of the Goods and Chattels of the Offender or Offenders, by Warrant under the Hand and Seal of any Justice of the Peace for the said County of Carlow, or County of the City of Kilkenny, where the Offence shall happen, (which Warrant such Justice is hereby empowered to grant upon the Confeflion of the Party, or upon the Evidence of any credible Witness upon Oath), and the Overplus, if any, of the Money arising by such Distress and Sale shall be returned upon Demand to the Owner of such Goods and Chattels, after deducting the Costs and Charges oF making, keeping, and felling the Distress; and such Penalties and For* feitures when recovered (if not herein-before directed to be otherwise applied) shall be paid to the Treasurer to the said Trustees, to be applied towards the Purposes of this Act; and in case sufficient Distress shall not be found, or such Penalties and Forfeitures shall not be paid forthwith, it shall and may be lawful to and for such Justice, and he is hereby authorized and required, by Warrant under his Hand and Seal, to cause the Offender or Offenders to be committed to the Common Gaol or House of Correction of the County, City, or Place, where the Offence shall have been committed, there to remain without Bail or Mainprize for any Time not exceeding Three Calendar Months nor less than Twenty-one Days, unless such Penalties and Forfeitures, and all reasonable Charges attending the Recovery thereof, shall be sooner fully paid and satisfkd.

Appeal. LX VII. Provided always, and be it further enacted, That if any Person or

Persons shall think himself, herself, or themselves, aggrieved by any Thing done in pursuance of this Act, such Person or Persons may appeal to the Justices of the Peace at the First General or Quarter Sessions of the Peace to be holden for the County or Place within which the Matter of Appeal shall arise next after the Expiration of Six Calendar Months from the Time such Matter of Appeal shall have arisen, the Person or Persons appealing having first given Twenty Days Notice at least of his, her, or their Intention to bring such Appeal, and of the Matter thereof, to the Treasurer or Clerk to the said Trustees, and within Four Days after such Notice entering into a Recognizance before some Justice of the Peace for such County, with sufficient Sureties conditioned to try such Appeal, and abide the Order and Award of the said Court thereon; and th e said Justices at such Sessions, upon due Proof of such Notice and Recognizance having been given and entered into, are hereby authorized and required to hear and determine the Matter of such Appeal in a summary Way, and to make such Determination therein, and to award such Costs to either of the Parties, or otherwise as they Ih .11 judge proper; and all such Determinations shall be final, binding, and conclusive to all Parties, to all Intents and Purposes whatsoever.

LXVIII. And be it further enacted, That where any Distress shall be made for any Sum of Money to be levied by virtue of this Act, the Distress Itself shall not be deemed unlawful, nor the Party or Parties making the same be deemed a Trespasser or Trespalfers on Account of any Defect or want of Form in the Information, Summons, Conviction, Warrant of Distress, or other Proceedings relating thereto; nor shall the Party or Parties distraining be deemed a Trespasser or Trespasser, ab initio, on Account of any Irregularity which shall be afterwards done by the Party or Parties so distraining; but the Person or Persons aggrieved by such Irregularity, shall and may recover full Satisfaction for the special Damage in an Action upon the Cafe.

45° GEORGII III. Gap.$t.

Action; nor shall the Plaintiff or Plaintiffs recover in any such Action, if Tender of sufficient Amends hath been made to him, her, or them, or to his, her, or their Attorney, by or on the Behalf of the Defendant or Defendants before such Action brought; and in case no such Tender shall have been made, it shall and may be lawful to and for the Defendant or Defendants in any such Action, by leave of the Court after such ASion shall have been brought, at any Time before Ifl'ue joined, to pay into Court such Sum of Money as he, she, or they shall think fit, whereupon such Proceedings, Order, and Judgement shall be made and given in and by such Court, as in other Adioas where the Defendant is allowed to pay Money into Court.

LXXI. Provided always, and be it further enacted, That no Action Limitation or Suit shall be commenced against any Person or Persons for any Thing of Action., done in pursuance of this Act after Three Calendar Months next after the Fad committed; and every such Action or Suit shall be brought and tried in the County where the Cause of Action shall arise and not elsewhere; and if any such Action or Suit shall be brought before Twenty Days Notice shall have been given, or after sufficient Satisfaction, made or tendered as aforesaid, or after the Time limited for bringing the fame as aforesaid, or shall be brought in any other County than as aforesaid, then and in every such Case the Jury shall find for the Defendant or Defendants; and upon such Verdict, or if the Plaintiff or Plaintiffs shall be nonsuited or discontinue his, her, or their Action or Suit, after the Defendant or Defendants shall have appeared, or if upon Demurrer Judgement shall be given against the Plaintiff or Plaintiffs, then and in every such Case the Defendant or Defendants shall recover Treble Costs, and have such Remedy for recovering the fame as any Defendant hath for Costs of Suit in other Cafes by Law.

LXXQ. And be it further enacted, That this Act shall be deemed, r*bli:k Act4 adjudged, and taken to be a Publick Act, and shall be judicially taken Notice of as such by all Judges, Justices, and other Persons, without being specially pleaded.

LXXIII. And be it further enacted, That this Act shall commence and Contjnu*nc* take place on the Twenty.first Day of June after the passing thereof, of thl5 Act' and shall be in Force and have Continuance for and during the Term of Twenty-one Years, and from thence to the End of the then next Session of Parliament.

And be it further enacted, That the Certificate or Certificates of the said Accountant General, together with the Receipt or Receipts of one of the Cashiers of the Bank, to be thereunto annexed and therewith filed in the Register Office of the said Court of Chancery, of the Payment into the Bank of England, by the Person or Persons becoming the Purchaser or Purchasers of the Hereditaments hereby authorized to be sold, or in whose favour such Enfranchisement or Enfranchisements shall be made of his or their Putchafe Monies respectively, or of such Part or Parts thereof as shall not have been paid in discharge of Incumbrances, according to the Authority herein-before given, or of any Part of such Purchase Monies, shall, from Time to Time, be, and be deemed to be, good and effectual Discharges to such Person and Persons, and to his or their respective Heirs, Executors, Administrators, and A(sign«, for tha said Purchase Monies, or so much thereof, for which such Certificates and Receipts shall be respectively given; and after filing such Certificates and Receipts as aforesaid, such Person and Persons shall be absolutely acquitted and discharged of and from the same Monies, and shall not be answerable or accountable for any Loss, Misapplication, or Non-application thereof.

IX. And whereas the Purchase Money to be paid for the said Manors and Estates so contrafted for by the said Charles now Duke of Norfolk, as aforesaid, will amount to a large Sum; and it may be some Time before such a Sum can be raised by Sale of the fame Estates, as will be equal to the Amount of the Purchase Money to be paid for the Estates contrafted for as aforesaid; and from the Nature and Situation of the major part of the Estates hereby made saleable (which consist of ftnall Tenements situated in and near the large manufacturing Town of Sheffield, in the County of York) the fame would not bring such large Prices if the Trustees were obliged to raise so large a Sum, within a limited Time, as would be re-quifite to complete the said Contraft, and without being able to make 7 use.

X. And be it also enacted, That it shall be lawful for the said Court of Chancery, upon Application, in a summary Way as aforesaid, to order the Payment of such Part of the said Purchase Money as shall be secured in Manner aforesaid, out of the Monies to arile from the Sales of the Estates hereby made saleable as aforesaid, at such Times, and in such Manner, as the said Court shall think fit.

XII. Provided also, and be it further enacted, That in case of any such Mortgage being made of the Estates so contracted to be purchased as aforesaid, all and every the Estates made saleable by this Act, which shall then remain unfold, shall, until the Sale thereof, under the Powers herein contained, remain veiled in the said Trustees and their Heirs, upon Trust, to secure and indemnify the Estates so contracted to be purchased, from the Trincipal Money to be secured by the said Mortgage.

XIII. And be it further enacted, That in the mean Time, and until such Sales shall be made as aforesaid, of the Hereditaments hereby authorised to be sold, they the said Thomas IVybergh and Vincent Henry Eyre, and the Survivor of them, and his Heirs, shall permit and fuller the Rents and Profits of the said Hereditaments to be had, received and taken by such Person or Persons as would respectively have been entitled to, and ought to have held, received and enjoyed the fame, in case this Act had not been made.

XIV. Provided always, and it is hereby further enacted, That if both, or either of them, the said Thomas IVybergh and Vincent Henry Eyre, or any future Trustee or Trustees who shall succeed to them, or either of them, pr shall be appointed in the Stead or Place of them, or either of them, as herein-after mentioned, shall die or desire to relinquish the Trusts hereby in them or him reposed, or shall refuse or decline to ad, or become incapable to ad in the said Trusts, or shall go out of Great Britain before the said Trusts shall be fully performed and executed, then and so often as any such Case shall happen, it shall be lawful for the said Charles now Duke of Norfolk, or such Person as for the Time being would be beneficially entitled in Possession, according to the Uses limited by the Settlements herein-before recited, to the Hereditaments hereby made saleable; or if such Person shall be an Infant, then for his Guardian or Guardians, by any Writing or Writings under his Hand and Seal, or their Hands and Seals, and to be attested by Two or more credible Witnesses from Time to Time to nominate, substitute, and appoint any Person or Persons to be a Trustee or Trustees in the Stead or Place of the Trustee or Trustees so dying or desiring to be discharged, or going out of Great Britain, or refusing, declining, or becoming incapable to act as aforesaid; a..d that when, and so soon, and as often as any new Trust e or Trustees shall be nominated and appointed as aforesaid, and such Nomination and Appointment shall have been approved of, by an Order of the said Court of Chancery, in a summary Way, on a Petition by the Person or Persons making such Nomination or Appointment, or any Person beneficially interested, all the Trull, Eltates and Premises

XV. Provided always, and it is hereby enacted and declared, That nothing in this Act contained shall extend to prejudice or affect the Most Noble Frances Duchess of Norfolk, the Wife of the said Charles now Duke of Norfolk, or her Assigns, in respect of the yearly Sum of Three hundred Pounds secured for the said Duchess, by Way of additional Pin Money, or the yearly Sum of One thousand Pounds, also secured for the said Duchess, by Way of additional Jointure, by a certain Indenture bearing Date the Twenty-eighth Day of February One thousand seven hundred and seventy-eight, made between the said Charles now Duke of Norfolk, and the said Duchess, of the one Part; and the Right Honourable Charles late Lord Southampton, by his then D.scription of the Honourable Charles Fitzroy, Btother of the Most Noble Augustus Duke of Grafton, and Sir Hungerford Hojkins Baronet, of theother Part; and which additional Jo nture was’so secured by the Appointment of the said Charleses ow Duke of Norfolk, under the Power of jointuring herein-before mentioned to be contained in the said Indentu e of Eight Parts, of the Eleventh Day of June One thousand seven hundred and sixty-seven, or in respect of any Powers or Terms of Years given and created for securing the said additional Pin Money and additional Jointure; but that Ihe the said Frances Duchess of Norfolk, and her Assigns, and her Trustees, shall in respect of the said additional Pin Money and yearly Sum for additional Jointure, have the fame Right, Title, and Interest, Terms of Years, or other Estate, as Ihe and they had, or might or could have had, in case this Act had not been made.

XVI. Provided nevertheless, and it is hereby further enacted, That it shall be lawful for the said Court of Chancery, in the Settlements to be made of the Estates to be purchased and settled in pursuance of this Act, to direct such Provision to be inserted, far the Indemnity of the Purchasers of the Estates hereby made fal.-able, against the said Pin Money and additional Jointure, as the said Court of Chancery shall deem proper.

XVII. II. And be it further enacted, That the said George Lord Ashburnham, and ’John Forjler, rhrir Heirs and Assigns, shall (land and be feiltd of the faiu Messuages, Lands, Tenements, cr Hereditaments, upon and for such Trusts, Inrents, anti Purposes, and with, under, and subjedf to such Powers, Pro'Hues, Declarations, and Agreements, as would be now lubfifting or capable of taking Effect in the fame or any Part or Parts of the fame, by virtue of the said recited Indentures or Wills, if the said Manors, Messuages, Lands, Tenements, or Hereditaments, instead of having been conveyed unto and to the Use of the said Sir Mattbeve Lamb and William Varey, their Heirs and Assigns, had been conveyed unto and to the Use of the said George Lord Ajblurnbam and John Forjler, their Heirs and Assigns, and the Estates, Trusts, Powers, and Authorities by the said ric t<-d Indentures or Wills, or any of them, or other wise given ro the said Sir Matthew Lamb and William Varey, their Heirs, Executors, Administrators, or Assigns, or to them the said Sir Matthew Lamb and William Varey, or the Survivor of them, or the Heirs, Executors, Administrators, or Assigns of such Survivor, had been respectively given to the said George Lord Ashburnham and John Forjler, their Heirs, Executors, Administrators, or Assigns, or to them the said George Lord /ijhburnham and John Forjler or the Survivor of them, or the Heirs, Executors, Administrators, or Assigns of such Survivor.

III. Saving always to the King’s\ most Excellent Majesty, His Heirs and Succctibr?, and to all Bodies Politick and Corporate, his, her, and their Heirs and Successors, Executors and Administrators, and to all and every o;her Persons and Person whomsoever (other than and except His said Majesty, his Heirs and Successors, as to any Estate, Right, or Title which he cr they now hath or have, or hereafter may or might have in t>r to the fame, by Elcheat, for want of an Heir to the said William Varey, and also other than and except any Heirs or Heir at Law of the said William Varey), all such Rights, Estates, Interests, Claims, and Demands whatsoever, which they, every, or any of them, might have in, to, from, out of, or upon the said Messuages, Lands, Tenements, and Hereditaments, or any of them, in case this present Act had not been made.

IV. And be it further enacted, That this Act shall be printed by the Printer to the King’s most Excellent Majesty, and a Copy thereof, lb printed. Anil be admitted as Evidence thereof by all Judges, Justices, and others.

LONDON: Printed by George Eyrf. and Andrew' Straiian, Printers to the King’s most Excellent Majesty. 1805.

Cap. 56.

An Act to continue the Term, and alter and enlarge the Powers of an Act made in the Twenty-seventh Year of His present Majesty, for repairing the Road leading from Berwick-upon-Tweed by Ay ton Bridge to Dung las Bridge, and also the Roads from Billie causeway and Preston Bridge, to join the said Road,> at or near Cockburnfpath Tower, in the County of Berwick. [27th June 1805.]

WHEREAS by an Act passed in the Twenty-seventh Year of the Reign of His present Majesty, intituled, An Act for repairing arid widening the Road leading from the Borough of Berwick-upon-Tweed by Ayton Bridge and the new Bridge over the Pecs or Pass of Cockburnfpath to Dunglas Bridge, and also the Roads leading from Billie causeway and Preiton Bridge, to join the said Road at or near Cockburnfpath 1 owep in the County ^'Berwick, l'sveral Toils and Duties were [loc. granted and made payable, and divers Powers and Authorities were given for repairing the said Roads: And whereas great Progress has been made in repairing the said Roads, but the fame cannot be carried on and completed, nor the said Roads kept in Repair, unless the Term and Powers of the said Act be further continued and enlarged: And whereas the great Port Road from Berwick-upon-Tweed to Dungias Bridge has been found by Experience to be in manyPIaces fteepand incommodious, and those Defects cannot be remedied, unless the Lineand Direction of the said Road is altered and improved, which cannot be effebted without the Authority of Parliament, and without increasing the Tolls and enlarging the Powers granted by the before recited Act: May it therefore please Your Majesty

that it may be enacted; and be it enacted by the King’s rood Excellent Majesty, by and with the Advice and Consent of the Lords Spiritual and Temporal, and Commons, in this present Parliament assembled, and by the Authority of the same, That the said recited Act of the Twenty-seventh Year of the Reign of His present Majesty, and all and every the Clauses, Exemptions, Powers, Authorities, Articles, Rules, Penalties, Forfeitures, Matters, and Things therein contained (except in so far as they are altered or varied by this present Act), shall continue and be executed for and during the Term herein-after mentioned, as fully and effectually, to all Intents and Purposes, as if the said recited Act was hereby repeated and reenabled; which said additional Term is hereby declared to be subject and liable to the Payment of all Sums of Money now due and owing on the Credit of the said recited Act, and of such of the Sum or Sums of Money as shall or may be borrowed for the Purposes of the said Act or this Act, and of all Interest now due or to grow due for the fame respectively.

II. And be it enacted, That every Heritor who is or shall be in his own Right, or in the Right of his Wife, in the Possession and Enjoyment, as Fiar or Liferenter, of the full Property or Dominium Utile of Lands in the County of Berwick, rated in the Land Tax Roll or Valuation Books of the said County at One hundred Pounds Scots of valued Rent, and all and every the eldest Sons of such Persons, and also the Chief Magistrate of the Burgh of Lauder, the Mayor, Recorder, and Justices of Peace of the Borough of Berwick upon-Tweed, and the Two Members of Parliament for the said Borough of Berwick, all for the Time being, although the said Chief Magistrate of Lauder, and the Mayor, Recorder, Justices of the Peace, and Members of Parliament for the Borough of Berwick, or either of them, are not possefTed of Lands to the above Extent, shall be Trustees for putting in Execution the before recited Act and this present Act; and there shall from henceforth be veiled in the said Trustees every Right, Interest, and Property, and the whole Powers, Privileges, and Authorities which were formerly vested in or did belong to the Trustees named by the said recited Act; and they may levy or cause to be levied the Tolls granted by the said Act or by this present Act for and during the Continuance of the fame.

III. And be it further enacted, That if any Person not qualified or appointed as aforesaid shall neverthelei's presume to act as a Trustee, every such Person shall for every such Acting forfeit the Sum of Twenty

or from the Yards or Offices of the Inhabitants of Towns or Villages lying along the Line of the said Road to Fields adjoining to any such Town or Village occupied by such Inhabitant, where there are no Yards or Offices; nor for Corn, Flour or Meal, going to or returning from any Mill belonging to and to be consumed by the Inhabitants of the Parish in which such Mill is situated; nor for Carriages or Horses carrying Stone, Lime, and Timber, or other Materials for building or inclosing from one Part of a Proprietor’s Estate to another Part thereof, whether in the said County, or the adjoining Counties j nor for Horses and other Cattle going to or returning from Pasture or Wateing Places, or any Smithy, in the fame or next adjoining Parish; nor for Carriages or Horses carrying any Person to or from Church, Chapel, or other Place of Religious Worship, belonging to or situated within the Parish where such Person refutes, on Sunday, or any other Day on which Divine Service is ordered by u-thority to be celebrated; or attending the Funeral of any Person who shall die and be buried within the Parish; or carrying 3iiy Clergyman going to or returning from visiting any sick Person, or upon other his parochial Duty, on a Sunday, or on any other Day on which Divine Service is ordered by Authority to be celebrated; nor for Carriages and Horses of whatever Description, employed in conveying the Mails of Letters or Expresses under the Authority of His Majesty’s>Poli-master General, either when employed in conveying such Mails or Ex* prefles, or in returning back from conveying the fame; nor for Horses belonging to Officers or Soldiers upon their March or upon Duty; nor for Horses, Cattle, or Carriages employed in carrying or conveying the Arms or Baggage of any such Officers or Soldieis, or carrying any wounded or disabled Officers or Soldiers; nor for Horses furnished by or for any Persons belonging to any Corps of Yeomanry or Volunteer Cavalry, and rode by them, in going to or returning from the Place appointed for, or on the Days of Exercise, provided that such Persons be cloathed in the Uniform of their respective Corps, and have their Arms, Furniture, and Accoutrements, according to the Regulations provided for such Corps respectively, at the Time of claiming such Exemption; nor for Carts, Carriages, or Waggons travelling with Vagrants and Criminals under legal PalTes; and it any Person shall in any Manner claim and take the Benefit of any of the Exemptions hereby granted, not being entitled to the fame, every such Person shall, for every such Offence, forfeit and pay any Sum not exceeding Forty Shillings Sterling, nor less than Ten Shillings Sterling, One Moiety whereof shall go to the Informer, and the other Moiety shall be applied to the Purposes of this Act.

XII. XXXI. And be it enacted, That the Term granted by the said Act shall, from and after the passing hereof, cease and determine; and that the said Act, and this Act, shall from thenceforth continue and be in force for and during the Term of Twenty-one Years, and from thence to the End of the then next Session of Parliament.

GEORGII III. REGIS.

*v*

Cap. 57.

An Act for continuing the Term, and altering and enlarging the Powers of an Act passed in the Thirty-sixth Year of His present Majesty, for repairing the Road leading from Crofsford Bridge, in the County Palatine of La?icaster, to Altrincham, in the County Palatine of Chester. [27thy«£1805.]

WHEREAS an Act was passed in the Thirty-sixth Year of the Reign of His present Majesty, intituled, An Act for repairing 3CG.3. c. t and amending the Road leading from Crofsford Bridge within Stretford, in the County Palatine of Lancaster, to Altrincham, in the County Palatine of Chester: And whereas the Trustees appointed in or by virtue of the said Act have made great Progress in repairing the said Road, and have for that Purpose borrowed very considerable Sums of Money upon Credit of the Tolls thereby granted, which Money still remains due and owing; and the Money so due and owing cannot be repaid, nor can the said Road be effectually amended, improved, and kept in Repair, unless the Term of the said Act be continued, and the Tolls thereby granted be increased, and the Powers and Provisions of the said Act altered, amended, and enlarged: May it therefore please Your Majesty that it may be enacted; and be it enacted by the King’s most Excellent Majesty, by and with the Advice and Consent of the Lords Spiritual and Temporal, and Commons, in this present Parliament assembled, and by the Autho-[L«. Cif Perd]; xa / rity

XIII. Provided also, and be it further enacted, That where, by reason of any Disability or Incapacity of the Person or Persons, or Corporation, entitled to any Lands, Tenements, or Hereditaments, to be purchased under the Authority of the said recited Act and this Act, the Purchase Money for the same shall be required to be paid into me Court of Chancery, and to be applied in the Purchase of other Lands, Tenements, or Hereditaments, to be settled to the like Uses, in pursuance of the said recited Act and this Act, it shall and may be lawful ‘to and for the said Court of Chancery to order the Expences of all Purchases from Time to Time to be made in pursuance of the said recited Act and this Act, or so much of such Expences as the said Court shall deem reasonable, to be paid by the said Trustees out of the Monies to be received by virtue of the said recited Act and this Act, who shall from Time to Time pay such Sums of Money for such Purposes as the said Court shall direct.

XIV. And be it further enacted, That this Act shall be deemed and taken to be a I’ublick Act, and be judicially taken Notice of as such, by all Judges, Justices, and others, without being specially pleaded.

XV. And be it further enacted, That the Term granted and continued by the said recited Act, shall, on the passing of this Act, cease and determine; and that the said Act and this Act shall from thenceforth commence, continue, and be in force, and be executed for and during the Term of Twenty-one Years, and from thence to the End of the then next Session of Parliament.

Cap. 58.

An Act to alter and amend an Act, passed in the Fortieth Year of the Reign of His present Majesty, for making Wet Docks, Basons, Cuts, and other Works, for the greater Accommodation and Security of Shipping, Commerce, and Revenue, within the Port of London \ and for extending the Powers and Provisions of the said Act. [27th June 1S05.J

WHEREAS an Act was passed in the Fortieth Year of the Reign

of His present Majesty, intituled, An Act for making VlTet Docks, 41 G. 3. Basons, Cuts, and other Works, for the greater Accommodation and Security of Shipping, Commerce, and Revenue, within the Port of London: And whereas certain Persons therein named and described, and who were to be thereafter called The London Dock Company, were empowered to construd and make certain Basons, Docks, Quays, Wharfs, and other Works, within certain Limits therein mentioned, in order to provide for the Safety and Accommodation cf Ships and Vessels frequenting the said Port of London, and otherwise for carrying into Execution the Purposes of the said Act: And whereas the said Company were also empowered to contribute, raile, receive, and apply certain Sums of Money, for carrying the Purposes of the said Act into Execution: And whereas an Act was passed in the Forty-fourth Year of the Reign of His present Majesty, intituled, An Act for raising a further Sum of Money for carrying [Lee. fcf Ar.j) 12 L into

into Execution an Act passed in the Fortieth Year of the Reign of His present Majesty, for making Wet Docks, Bafous, Cuts, and other Works, for the greater Accommodation and Security of Shipping, Commerce, and Revenue within the Port of London, by which the said London Dock Company were enabled to raise a further Slim of Money for carrying into Execution the Purposes of the said recited Act, and the iame hath been accordingly raised: And whereas great Progress hath been made in executing the Works by the said first recited Act authorized and directed to be. made and construded, and the principal Dock hath been finished and is now in use, but the Whole of the said intended Works cannot be completed according to the Intentions and Directions of the said first recited Act, unless the said Company are authorized to raise a further additional Sum of Money for that Purpose: And whereas it is necessary that the said first-mentioned Act should be altered and amended, and that the Powers and Authorities given to the said Company should be further extended and enlarged for the Completion of the said Docks, and the more effectual carrying into Execution the Purposes of the said first recited Act: May it therefore please Your Majesty that it may be enacted; and be it enacted by the King’s most Excellent Majesty, by and with the Advice and Consent of the Lords Spiritual and '1 emporal, and Commons, in this present Parliament assembled, and by the Authority of the same, That so much of the said first recited Act as requires that the Two Yearly General Courts of the said London Dock Company should be held on the First Wednesday in the Month of July, and on the First Wednesday in the Month of January respectively in each Year, shall be, and the fame is hereby repealed; and from and after the passing of this Act the Yearly General Courts of the said Company may and shall be held, One thereof on any Day within the first Twenty Days of the Month of January, and the other thereof on any Day within the first Twenty Days of the Month of July, of which respective Meetings Seven Days Notice shall be given by Publication in the London Gazette, and two daily Newspapers usually circulated in London, and by fixing up such Notice at the Royal Exchange, and in the Guildhall of the City of London.

XII. And whereas by the said first recited Act, Provision is made for preventing Tar and other combustible Matters from remaining on the said Quays or Wharfs, or upon the Deck of any Ship or ether Vessel in the said Basons or Docks, Cuts or other Works, above the Space of Twelve Hours after passing the Custom House Officers: And whereas it is expedient that such Provision should be repealed, and that more effectual Regulations for preventing the Mischiefs thereby intended to be provided against should be made: Be it therefore enacted, That so much of the said fnft-mentioned AS as relates to the Removal of the said combustible Matters, and the Penalties for Non-compliance with the DireSions of the said AS in that Behalf, shall be, and the fame is and are hereby repealed, and declared to be null and void to all Intents arid Purposes whatsoever.

XIII. And be it further enacted, That if the Owner or Owners of or the Person or Persons in or to whose Custody or Charge any 'l ar, Pitch, Rosin, Hemp, Flax, Faggots, Furze, Brandy, or other Spirituous Liquors, Turpentine, Oil, Hay, Straw, Tallow, Grease, Shavings of Wood, or any other Combustible Matter whatsoever shall be or be entrusted, shall permit or suffer the fame or any of them, or any Part thereof relpeSively, to be and remain on the Quays or Wharfs aforesaid, or any Part thereof, or upon the Deck of any Ship, Lighter, Barge, Boat, or other Vessel in the said Basons or Docks, Cuts or other Works, or any of them, above

XIV. And for the better making and preserving of a free and clear Entrance, Navigation, and Passage into and out of the said Docks, Basons, and Cuts; be it further enacted, That if any Master or other Person having the Charge or Command of any Ship, Lighter, Barge, Boat, or other Vessel of any Description whatsoever, shall place or permit, or suffer the fame to remain in the River Thames, within Two hundred Yards of the Entrance of any of the said Docks, Basons, or Cuts, and shall not immediately, on being the reunto required by the Dock Master or Dock Masters, remove such Ship, Lighter, Barge, Boat, or other Vessel, every such Master and other Person so offending shall for every such Offence forfeit and pay any Sum not exceeding Ten Pounds, and also any Sum not exceeding Five Pounds, for every Hour that such Obstruction shall remain after such Requisition made.

Cap. 59.

An Act to empower the Justices of the Peace within the Division or Hundred of Salford, in the County Palatine of Lancaster, to raise a Sum of Money, to be paid by way of Salary to the Chairman of the Quarter Sessions for the said Hundred.

« - [27th June 1805.]

WHEREAS from the Magnitude and Importance of the Business of the General Quarter Sessions of the Peace, held by Adjournment in the Parish of Manchester, in the County of Lancajleri owiflg to the very extensive Population of the District, and the prevailing and increasing Influence of its Trade and Manufactures, the Situation of Chairman of the said Quarter Sessions hath become and is likely to continue very burdensome and difficult; and it is therefore expedient that the Justice acting in that Situation should be duly qualified, by his Knowledge of the Law, to discharge the Duties of it, and should receive some competent Remuneration for his Trouble: May it therefore pieafe Your Majesty that it may be enacted; and be it enacted by the King’s most Excellent Majesty, by and with the Advice and Consent of the Lords Spiritual and Temporal, and Commons, in this present Parliament assembled, and by the Authority of the same, That at the next General justices witH:n Quarter Sessions of the Peace for the County Palatine of Lancaster, to be the Hua«tr-J held within the Hundred and Division of Salford, in the said County, after the Qgulu* [Loc, Is? Per.] 12 0 the Sclliuns, re*

io66

quired to appoint a Chairman duly qualified.

Appointments

in ofe of Vacancies.

Power to raise a Salary not exceeding 4001. cut of the Kates of the Hundred.

45° GEORGII III. Cap. 59.

the pnfling of this Act, and from Time to Time afterwards, whenever the Office shall be vacant, or any new Appointment shall become necessary under this Act, the Justices of the Peace acting within the said Hundred of Salford, in the said County, assembled at the General Quarter Sessions of the Peace for the said County, holden within the said Hundred and Division, or the major Part of them, or at some Adjournment thereof to be made for that Purpose, shall and they are hereby authorized and empowered, when and so often as they shall deem it fit and necessary to do so, to elect, nominate, and appoint, from and out of His Majesty’s Justices of the Peace for the said County, a fit and proper Person, duly qualified by his Knowledge and Experience in the Law, and who shall have attained the Degree of Barrister, to be Chairman of the General Quarter Sessions of the Peace to be from Time to Time holden within the said Hundred; which said Person so to be nominated and appointed, shall from thenceforth be and officiate as Chairman of the said Quarter Sessions, and shall, so long as he shall remain in the Commission of the Peace for the said County, and difehafge the Duties of such Office, be tntitled to receive the Salary herein-after provided for the fame.

II. Provided always, That in case the said Office shall be vacant by Death, Uefignation, or otherwise, or the Person appointed thereto shall not continue to discharge the Duties thereof, or shall not remain in the Commission of the Peace for the said County, no new Nomination and Appointment to the said Office shall be permanent, unless the same shall be made and confirmed at some adjourned Sessions to be holden within the said Division, at lead Twenty-eight Days after Notice in Writing of such Vacancy, and of such adjourned Sessions, shall be given by the Clerk of the Peace or his Deputy, for the said County, to each of the Justices acting and resident within the said Division; which said Notice the said Clerk of the Peace or his Deputy is hereby directed to give, by Letter addressed to each of the said Justices at his usual Place of Residence, and by Publication in One or more of the Manchester Newspapers: Provided also, that the said Clerk of the Peace or his Deputy shall, within Fourteen Days after such Vacancy shall be known to him, notify the fame to the said Justices, by Letter addressed to them respectively as aforesaid, and by Publication in One or more of the said Newspapers.

III. And be it further enacted, That it shall and may be lawful for the Justices assembled at the General Quarter Sessions of the Peace held within the said Hundred, or at any Adjournment thereof, from Time to Time to make a Rate or Assessment upon the said Hundred, to levy and raise the Sum of Four hundred Pounds, over and above the Expenses of levying the fame in any one Year, to be paid into the Hands of the Clerk of the Peace for the said County or his Deputy, who shall, and is hereby required to pay the fame unto such Chairman so to be elected and appointed as aforesaid, by Four Quarterly Payments to be appointed by the said Justices, as an annual Stipend or Salary, and as a Compensation for the Trouble of such Chairman; the fame to be assessed, levied, and raised by the said Justices, in such and the like Manner as the County Rates are now assessed, levied, and raised within the said Hundred, and with such and the like Powers, Authorities, and Remedies for collecting the fame, as are mentioned and contained in an Act of Parliament made

in

IV. And be it further enacted, That the Expences incident to the Expends of soliciting, obtaining, and passing of this Act, shall be levied and raised in p^/outo” the Manner aforesaid, out of the Kates of and for the said Hundred, and shall Rate* jf the be paid by and under the Order of the said Justices assembled at the Hundred* General Quarter Sessions of the Peace in the said Hundred.

V. And be it further enacted, That this Act shall be deemed and taken Publick Act. to be a Publick Act, and shall be judicially taken Notice of as such by all Judges, Justices, and others, without being specially pleaded.

GEORGII III. REGIS.

Cap. 61.

An Act to explain and amend an Act, passed in the Thirty-third Year of His late Majesty, for regulating the Proceedings in Personal Actions in the respective Courts Baron of the Hundred of High Peak and Manor of Cajlleton, in the County of Derby; and for extending the Powers of the said Courts.

[27th June 1805.]

WHEREAS an Act was passed in the Thirty-third Year of the Reign of His late Majesty King George the Second, intituled, An Act for regulating the Proceedings in Personal Actions in the respective Courts Baron of the Hundred of High Peak and Manor of Castleton, in the County of Derby: And whereas the King’s most Excellent Majesty, in Right of His Duchy of Lancaster, is seised to Him, ITis Heirs and Successors, of and in the Hundred and Liberty of High Peak and Manor of Cajlleton, and of the Jurisdictions of the Two several Courts Baron within and appertaining to the said Hundred and Manor respectively 2 And whereas from Time immemorial Plea hath been held every Three Weeks, or so often as requisite, in all Personal Actions arising within the Jurisdictions of the said several Courts Baron, where the Debt or Damage hath been under the Sum of Forty Shillings: And whereas under the Powers and Directions of the said recited Act, Justice hath in the most strict and impartial Manner from Time to Time been administered in the said several Courts Baron, to the great Benefit of the Inhabitants within the Jurisdiction of the fame respectively: And whereas the Jurisdiction of the said Hundred and Manor is very extensive, and comprises a very populous manufacturing and increasing District in the County of Derby, and the Town of Derby, where the superior Courts for the County are holden, is upwards of Forty Miles distant from the most populous Part of the said Hundred and Manor: And whereas on Account of the very great Expence attending the Recovery of small Debts of the Amount of Forty Shillings and upwards, in the superior Courts, many Creditors are discouraged from attempting to recover the Debts due to them, and [Lsr. isf Per.3 12 T many

jj G. J. c. ji.

io86

Powers of the Courts extended o Deb s under Five Pounds.

Courts not to determ'ne any Cause where the Title to the Land is brought into quell ion.

Teim of Imprisonment limited.

45° GEORGII III. Cap. 61.

many evil disposed Persons, who have contracted such fma'l Debts within the Jurisdiction of the said Hundred and Manor respectively, are enabled to refuse and delay, and do frequently refuse and delay the Payment thereof, to the manifest Injury of their just and lawful Creditors; and it would be of great Benefit and Advantage to the Inhabitants within the said Hundred and Manor respectively, if the Powers and Provisions of the said recited Act were extended to the Recovery of Debts and Damages of a larger Amount than Forty Shillings, and also if the said Act wete explained and amended and further Powers granted: May it thertfore please Your Majesty that it may be enacted; and be it enacted by the King’s most Excellent Majesty, by and with the Advice and Consent of the Lords Spiritual and Temporal, and Commons, in'this prefem Parliament assembled, and by the Authority of the same, That, from and after the passing of litis Act, it shall and may be lawful to and for the said fevertd Courts Baron of the said Hundred of High Peak and Manor of Cajlleton respectively, and the Stewards and Deputy Stewards thereof for the Time being, to proceed and hold Plea within the Jurisdiction of the said respective Courts, not only in anyPla.nt, Suit, or Action, for any Debt or Damages not exceeding the Sum of Forty Shillings, but also in any Plaint, Sui , or Action, for any Debt or Damages not exceeding the Sum of Five Pounds, which hath accrued, or shall or may at any Time or Times hereafter arise or accrue within the Jurisdiction of the fame Courts respectively, and to proceed in every such Plaint, Suit, or Action, in the fame or the like Manner and Form, and with and under such or the like Powers, Authorities, Rules, Regulations, Orders, and Directions as are authorized and directed, or have or might have been heretofore used or exercised in any Plaint, Suit, or Action for any Debt or Damages within the Jurisdiction of the said Courts respectively, not exceeding the Sum of Forty Shillings:

II. Provided always, and be it enacted, That nothing in the said recited Act or in this Act contained shall extend or be construed to extend so as to enable the said Courts, or either of them, to determine the Right or Title to any Lands, Tenements, or Hereditaments, or real Estates whatsoever, or to judge, determine, or decide on any Debt where the Title of the Freehold or Lease for Years of any Lands. Tenements, or Hereditaments, or of any Chattels real whatsoever shall be Drought or come into Question, or to judge, determine, or decide on any Debt that shall arise by reason of any Cause concerning Tellament or Matrimony, or any Thing concerning or properly belonging to the Ecclesiastical Court.

III. Provided nevertheless, That nothing in this Act contained shall extend, or be construed to extend to authorize (except in the Cafes hereinafter mentioned) the Imprisonment of any Person or Persons being a Debtor or Debtors, Defendant or Defendants, who shall be committed by the said respective Courts, or either of them, for any longer Space of Time from the Time of his, her, or their Commitment to Prison, than is or are herein-after limited; that is to say: Where the Debt, exclusive of Colts, does not exceed the Sum of Twenty Shillings, for more than Twenty Days; where the Debt does not exceed the Sum of Forty Shillings, for more than Forty Days; where the Debt does not exceed the Sum of Three Pounds, for more than Sixty Days; and where the Debt does not exceed the Sum of Five Pounds, for more than One hundred Days: Provided also, that all and every Person and Persons who shall be taken in Execution under or by virtue of any Process issued from or out of the said Courts respectively, and who, at the Time of being taken into Custody, or during his, her, or their Imprisonment, shall have more

5 than

[087

45° GEORGII III. Cap. 6r.

than One Execution against him, her, or them in the fame Court, shall be imprisoned the limited Time for and in respect of each Execution; any Law, Statute, or Usage to the contrary notwithstanding.

IV. And, in order the more effectually to prevent Persons summoned for Debts to the said Courts, or either of them, from the fraudulent Concealment of their Money or Goods; be it further enacted, That in case upon the Summons of any Person for any Debt or Debts before the said Courts, or either of them, Information of any such Practice shall be given, such Court and Courts shall have Power to hear Evidence as to such fraudulent Concealment, and in case it shall be proved to their Satisfaction upon the Oath of One or more Witness or Witnesses (which Oath the said Court or Courts is and are hereby empowered to administer) that any such Debtor has Money or Goods which he or she has wilfully and fraudulently concealed, then and in every such Case it shall and may be lawful to and for the said Courts, or either of them, to enlarge the aforesaid Time of Imprisonment for all Debts under 1 wenty Shillings to any Time not exceeding Thirty Days; and for Debts not exceeding Forty Shillings to any Time not exceeding Sixty Days; and for Debts not exceeding Three Pounds to any Time not exceeding Eighty Days; and for Debts not ex-deeding Five Pounds to any Time not exceeding One hundred and twenty Days, which said Circumstance or Ground for further Detention shall be specified on the said Commitment; and the Depositions of the Witnesses shall be entered in a Book kept for the Purpose by the Clerk of the said respective Courts.

V. And be it further enacted, That each and every Person imprisoned by virtue of the said recited Act or of this AS, shall, on the Expiration of his or her Time of Imprisonment, be discharged and set at Liberty without paying any Sum or Sums of Money, Fee or Fees or other Reward, or other Gratuity whatsoever, to the Keeper or Keepers, or Turnkey or Turnkeys of the said Gaol, or others, by way of Gaol Fees, or Discharge Fees, or on any other Pretence whalf jever; and if any Keeper or Keepers, Turnkey or Turnkeys of the said Gaol, or any other Person whomsoever, shall demand, take, or receive any Fee or Fees, Sum or Sums of Money whatsoever, upon the Discharge of any such Person or Persons so committed to his or their Charge or Custody as aforesaid, or shall keep or detain any such Person or Persons a Prisoner or Prisoners after the Time by this Act limited for his, her, or their Imprisonment, every such Keeper, Turnkey, and other Person, shall for every such Offence forfeit and pay the Sum of Five Pounds; and it shall and may be lawful to and for any Two Justices of the Peace for the said County of Derby to hear and determine every such Offence, and such Two Justices are hereby authorized and required upon any Information exhibited or Complaint made before them of any such Offence having been committed (in case such Information shall be exhibited or Complaint made within Three Calendar Months after the Offence committed) to summon the Party accused, and also the Witnesses on each Side, and to examine into the Matter of Fast; and upon due Proof made thereof by the Oath of One or more credible Witness or Witnesses, or by the voluntary Confeffton of the Party accused, to give Judgment or Sentence for such Penalty or Forfeiture aforesaid, and in case such Penalty or Forfeiture shall not be forthwith paid, to issue a Warrant under their Hands and Seals for levying such Penalty and Forfeiture, by Distrcfs and Sale of the Goods and Chattels of the Offender or Offenders, rendering the Overplus (if any) after deducting such Penalty and Forfeiture and the Costs and Charges of such Distrcfs and Sale, to the Owner or Owners thereof; and in case sufficient Distress shall not

VI. And be it further enacted, That it shall not be lawful to or for the said Courts, or either of them, to issue any Process against the Body or Bodies of any Person or Persons, in any Cafe or Ca es where the Party entitled to the Benefit of any Order, Judgement, or Decree, shall at the fame Time have obtained any Warrant or Process against the Goods and Chattels of the same Person or Persons.

VII. And be it further enacted, That no Action or Suit shall be commenced against any Person or Persons for any Thing done in pursuance of this or of the said recited Act, or on Account of any Order, Determination, Judgement, or Decree of the said Courts respectively, until Fourteen Days Notice shall be given thereof, in Writing, to be left at the Office of the Steward or Deputy Steward of the said respective Courts, nor after sufficient Satisfaction or Tender thereof, hath been made to the Party or Parties aggrieved, nor after Three Calendar Months next after the Cause of Action shall arise; and the Defendant or Defendants in such Action or Suit shall or may plead the General Issue, and give this Act and the Special Matter in Evidence; and that the Warrant or Precept under the respective Hands and Seals of the respective Stewards of the said Courts, or their respdctive Deputies, being duly proved in any Action or Suit, shall be deemed sufficient Proof of the Authority of the said Courts, and of all other Proceedings therein respectively, previously to the issuing of such Warrant or Precept; and in case the Plaintiff or Plaintiffs in such Action or Suit shall not duly prof.cute the fame, or shall have a Verdict pass agrainst him, her, or them, or shall be non-suited, or discontinue his, her, or their Action or Suit, the Defendant or Defendants shall in any of the said Cafes be entitled to and be allowed to recover Treble Costs of Suit.

VIII. And be it further enacted, That the said recited Act of the Thirty-third Year of the Reign of His late Majesty King George the Second, and all Powers, Provisoes, Clauses, Rules, Orders, Regulations, Re-strictions, Matters, and Things therein contained (except such Parts thereof as are hereby expressly altered or otherwise provided for, or are inconsistent with the Powers and Provisions of this present Act) shall continue and be in force, and shall relate and extend to the Purposes of this Act, so far as the same are applicable thereto, and shall be observed, exercised, and performed in such and the same Manner as if they had been expressly mentioned and repeated in the Body of this present Act.

IX. And be it further enacted, That this Act shall be deemed and taken to be a Publick Act, and shall be judicially taken Notice of as such by all Judges, Justices, and others, without being specially pleaded.

LONDON: Printed by George Eyre and Andrew Strahan, Printers to the King’s most Excellent Majesty. 1805.

And be it further enacted, That if any Disputes shall happen concerning any Tolls due, or the Charges occasioned by any such Distress as aforesaid, it shall be lawful for the Person or Persons so dillraining to retain such Distress, or the Money arising from the Sale thereof, until the Quantity of the Tolls, and the Charges of such Distress, shall be ascertained by some Justice of the Peace for the said County Palatine of Chtjltr, if such Distress shall have been taken on or nearest to the Chtshire Side of the said River Merfcy, or by some Justice of the Peace of the said Bo'ough of Liverpool, it the same shall have been taken nearer to the Lavcashire Side of the said River, who, upon Application made to him for that Purpose, shall examine the Matter on Oath of the Parties, or of a Witness or Witnesses, and shall determine the Toll due, and assess ihe Charges of such Distress, and of the Attendance upon such Justice for that Purpose, all which Sums so determined and assessed shall be paid to the Person making such Distress before he or she shall be obliged to return the Ankles or Things so distrained, or the Overplus or any Part thereof respedi vely.

V. And be it, further enacted, That where any such Distress or Dillreffes shall be made for any such Tolls or Compensations by virtue of this Act, the Distress itself shall not be deemed unlawful, nor the Party or Parties making the same be deemed a Trespasser or Trespasser on account of any Irregularity or want of Form in any Proceedings relating thereto; but the Person or Persons aggrieved by such Irregularity may recover Satisfaction for any Special Damage occasioned thereby, in an Action on the Cafe.

VI. Provided always, and be it further enacted, That if at any Time hereafter the said Joseph White, his Heirs or Assigns, or the Owner or Proprietor for the Time being, or any Lessee of the said Piers, Slips, or Quays shall permit or suffer either of the said Piers, Slips, or Quays, to become io much out of Repair that Persons, Horses, Cattle, Carts, and Carriages, cannot be safely landed, and the same shall be certified by any Two Justices of the Peace for the County Palatine of Chester as to the said Pier, Slip, or Quay, on the Gheshire Side, or by Two Justices of the Peace of the Town and Borough of Liverpool as io the said Pier, Slip, or Quay, on the Lar.cnshire Side of the said River Mcrfey, on View of such justices

VII. And be it further enacted, That if any Person or Persons shall art

IX. Provided always, and be it further enacted, That nothing in this Act contained shall give, or be deemed, construed, or taken it give any express or implied Power or Authority whatsoever, to the said Joseph White, his Heirs or Alligns, to build or to support or maintain the said Piers, Slips, or Quays, other than such as he the said Joseph White had or enjoyed before the passing of this Act; and that nothing herein contained 11.all in any way prevent or hinder any Body Corporate, Person or Persons whomsoever from proceeding at Law, either by \ftion, Indictment, or otherwise, for or on account of the said Buildings or Erections, in the lame Manner as if this Act had not been made.

X. Provided also, and be it enacted, That nothing in this Act contained shall extend or be conftfued to extend in any Manner to take away, alter, abridge, lessen, or change, any Right, Jurisdiction, Authority, or Power whatsoever, to the Mayor, Aldermen, Bailiffs, and Common Council of the Borough and Corporation of Liverpool, or any hf them belonging, in, about, concerning, or in respect of the Docks and Harbour of Liverpool, as the fame are settled and veiled in them by any Act or Acts of Parliament, or otherwise howsoever; and saving always and reserving to the Mayor, Bailiffs, and Burgesses of the Town of Liverpool aforesaid, all such Estates, Rights, Title, and Interest, which they enjoyed before the passing of this Act, or could or might have had or enjoyed in case this Act had not been made.

XI. Saving always to the King’s most Excellent Majesty, and to His Heirs and Successors, and to all and every ocher Person and Persons, Bodies Politick and Corporate, his, her, and their Heirs, Successors, Executors, and Administrators, all such Estates, Rights, Title, and In* terest (other than those meant and intended to be barred and destroyed by this Act) which they, every, or any of them had and enjoyed before the passing of this Act, or could or might have had or enjoyed in case this Act had not been made.

UL And whereas the Tolls by the said recited Acts authorized to be taken cm the said Second District of Road, have been found insufficient effectually to maintain and repair the fame, and pay the Interest of the Money borrow ed on the Credit of the said Tolls; be it therefore further enacted, That, from and immediately after the Commencement of this Act, the several Tolls now payable by virtue of the said recited Acts, on the said Second Didrift of Road, shall cease, determine, and be no longer payable; and that indead thereof the following Tolls shall be demanded and taken; that is to say,

Tor every Coach, Chariot, Landau, Berlin, Chaise, Sociable, Curricle, Phaeton, Calash, Caravan, or Hearse, drawn by Six or more Horses, Mares, Geldings, or Mules, the Sum of Two Shillings; and drawn by Four Horses, Mares, Geldings, or Mules, the Sum of One Shilling and Sixpence; and drawn by Three Horses, Mares, Geldings, or Mules, the Sum of One ShilUng and Three-pence; and drawn by Two Horses, Mares, Geldings, or Mules, the Sum of Nine-pence

For every Chaise, Whiskey, Gig, or Chair, drawn by One Horse, Mare, Gelding, or Mule, the Sum of Sixpence

For every Horse, Mare, Gelding, Mule, or Afs, laden or unladen, and not drawing, the Sum of One Penny Halfpenny

For every Drove of Oxen, Cows, or Neat Cattle, the Sum of Ten-pence per Score, and fb in proportion for any less Number:

For every Drove of Calves, Hogs, Sheep, or Lambs, the Sum of Five-pence per Score, and so in proportion for any less Number:

For every Waggon, Wain, Cart, or Carriage, drawn by Four or more Horses, Oxen, or other Beasts of Draught, the Sum of Sixpence; and drawn by Three Horses, Oxen, or other Beasts of Draught, the Sum of Four Pence Halfpenny; and drawn by Two Horses, Oxen, or other Beasts of Draught, the Sum of Three-pence; and drawn by One Horse, Ox, or other Bead of Draught, the Sum of Two-pence

Which said last-mentioned Tolls upon Waggons, Wains, Carts, and Carriages shall be demanded and taken for every Time each and every Waggon, Wain, Cart, or Carriage, shall pass or re-pass loaden through act, Gate or Turnpike now erected or to be erected upon the said Second Didrift of Road, or on the Sides thereof: Provided always, that no Person or Persons shall be liable to pay the said Tolls for or In respect of any such Waggon, Wain, Cart or Carriage, at more than Two Turnpikes or Toll Gates between the said Town of Rotherham and the End of Stubbing Lane, leading out of the said Road at a Place called *The Haugh, nor at more than Two Turnpikes or Toll Gates between, the End of Stubbing Lane and the present Turnpike Road on the Ead Side of Tankerjley Park aforesaid; any Thing in the said recited Acts or in this Act contained to the contrary thereofin any wise notwithstanding.

Cap. 65.

An Act to enable the Master, Pilots, and Seamen, of the Trinity House of Newcastle-upon-Tyne to erect Two new Lighthouses at North Shields, at or near the Port of Newcastle, and to raise a Fund for defraying the Charge thereof. [27th June 1805.]

WHEREAS the Master, Pilots, and Seamen, of the Trinity House of Newcastle-upon-Tyne, in the County of Newcastle-upon-Tyne, have been for a long Time a Corporation, by Virtue of Letters Patent from the Crown, bearing Date the First Day of July in the Third Year of the Reign of King James the Second, and have, under and by virtue thereof, levied, collected, and received, for and towards the Charges of repairing and keeping Two Lighthouses at North Shields, at or near the Port of Newcastle, for Marks for Ships entering into and departing from the said Port, and for Lights to be kept in them for the Night-time from Quarter and Half Quarter Flood and Half Ebb, certain Rates and Duties specified in the said Letters Patent, and paid by the Owners of Ships or Vessels entering the said Port, or any of the Creeks or Members thereof: And whereas by an A fit passed in the Forty-first Year of the Reign of His present Majesty, intituled, An Act for extending and enlarging the Powers, and increastng the Rates and Duties of the Corporation of the Trinity House of Newcastle-upon- yne, and for letter regulating the Port of Newcastle, in Confederation of the great Charge and Expence of supporting, maintaining, [Lee. fs* Per.] 13 D and.

Cap. 66.

An Act for building a Chapel in the Hamlet of Red-ditch, in the Parish of Tardebigg, in the Counties of W'oreefter and Warwick. [27th June 1805.]

WHEREAS the Chapel of Bord/ley, commonly called Redditch Chapel, in the Hamlet of Redditch in the Parish of Tardebigg, in the Counties of Worcester and Warwick, and Diocese of Worcester, was, about the Year One thousand six hundred and eighty, appropriated and set apart as a Place for Divine Worship, according to the Liturgy of the Church of England, and from that Time hath been used as such; and the said Chapel hath been hitherto repaired by Sub* feriptions, but is now in a very decayed and ruinous State and Condition, and the Roof and Ceiling thereof are so much decayed, that it has become unsafe for a Congregation to attend Divine Worship therein; and there is no known Fund applicable to the Repairs thereof, nor is it known that any Person or Persons is or are compellable to repair the fame: And whereas the Inhabitants of the Hamlet of Redditch have of late Years considerably increased, and the fame is now become very populousj and it would be a great Accommodation to the Inhabitants thereof, if [Lee. XXX. And whereas Divine Service hath heretofore been performed in the said Chapel, called Bordjlcy Chapel, only in the Afternoon of the Lord’s Day, and it would greatly tend to the Promotion of religious Worship, and to a drift Observance of the Sabbath, in the Hamlet of Redditch, if Divine Service were to be performed every Sunday in the Forenoon in the New Chapel intended to be erected by virtue of this Act; be it therefore further enacted, That it shall be lawful for any Clergyman of the Church of England, to be appointed by the present Vicar of 'Tardebigg, and his Succefifors, or by the Bishop of Worcester for the Time being, in Default of his or their Appointment within the Time hereinafter limited by the said Vicar, to perfoim Divine Service and preach a Sermon in such New Chapel in the Forenoon of every Lord’s Day, commonly called Sunday, and in the Forenoon of any other Day which shall be set apart by His Majesty’s Proclamation to be observed as a Day of Faffing or Thanks-giving, and also on Christmas Day and Good Friday, and on any other Day on which the Lord Bishop of Worcester for the Time being shall order Divine Worship to be ctlebrated in the said Chapel, and also upon the first Sunday in every Month (except in the Month of December, and the Months on which Easter Day and Whitsunday shall happen) shall administer the Holy Sacrament of the Lord’s Supper in the said New Chapel, according to the Rites and Ceremonies of the Church of England; and every Clergyman accepting such Appointment shall and is hereby required to peiform the Duty at the said Chapel in the Manner herein prescribed: Provided always, that nothing in this Act contained shall entitle such last-mentioned officiating Clergyman to have and receive any Stipend, Donation,

XXXIII. And be it further enacted, That this Act shall be deemed and taken to be a Publick Act, and shall be judicially taken Notice of as-such by all Judges, Justices, and others, without being specially pleaded.
